definition: χ, χεῖ (q.v.), τό, indecl., twenty-second letter of the Gr. alphabet, Pl. Cra. 414b, Ti. 36b. As numeral, χʹ = 600, ͵χ = 600,000: but in Inscrr., X stands for χίλιοι, αι, α, = 1000.

children.definition: ha! ha!, PMag.Leid.W. 4.33.
priestʼs robe, J. AJ 3.7.1 ( χαναίας codd.): a mistranslation of Aram. kāhǎnayyâ ‘priests’.
PCair.Zen. 680.20 (iii B. C.).
Hsch.; cf. χαμόν.
honey-pots, PSI 4.428.53 (iii B. C.).

definition: χαβῶνες στέατα ὀπτώμενα ἀπό ἀλεύρου, Hsch.
χάδην, f.l. for χαδέειν, aor. inf. of χανδάνω, Hp. Genit. 9.

children.definition: cause to retire; Act. only in Hsch. and in compd. ἀναχάζω (also παραχάζω, προχάζω Hsch.), and in Ep. redupl. aor. κέκᾰδον, fut. κεκᾰδήσω:— force to retire from, bereave or deprive of, τοὺς . . θυμοῦ καὶ ψυχῆς κεκαδών Il. 11.334; ἀριστῆας κεκαδήσει θυμοῦ καὶ ψυχῆς Od. 21.153, 170.

children.label: B
children.definition: Med., χάζομαι, Il. 5.34, etc.; imper. χάζεο, χάζευ, ib. 440, Call. Cer. 54: Ep. impf. χάζετο Il. 16.736, 3 du. χαζέσθην A.R. 3.1320: fut. χάσομαι, Ep. χάσσομαι Il. 13.153: aor. 1 ἐχᾰσάμην, Ep. 3 sg. χάσσατο ib. 193, inf. χάσσασθαι 12.172; part. χασσάμενος 13.148, etc.: κεκάδοντο (for κεχάδοντο) 3 pl. of redupl. aor. 2 κεκαδόμην, Il. 4.497, 15.574:— give way, draw or shrink back, recoil, freq. in Il. (never in Od.), χάζεο Il. 5.440; ὁ δὲ χασσάμενος πελεμίχθη 4.535; οὐδʼ ὅ γε πάμπαν χάζετʼ 12.407; ἂψ δʼ ἑτάρων εἰς ἔθνος ἐχάζετο 3.32, al.; αἰὲν ὀπίσσω χάζοντο 5.702, cf. 18.160, A.R. l.c., Call. l.c., Nonn. D. 48.618.

data.quote: ἂψ δʼ ἑτάρων εἰς ἔθνος ἐχάζετο

children.definition: draw back or retire from, πυλάων χάσσασθαι Il. 12.172; χάζοντο κελεύθου 11.504; χάζεσθε μάχης 15.426; μίνυνθα δὲ χάζετο δουρός 11.539; ὁ δὲ χάσσατʼ ὀπίσσω νεκρῶν 13.193, cf. 17.357; less freq. with a Prep., χ. ἐκ βελέων 16.122; χάσσονται ὑπʼ ἔγχεος 13.153; οὐδὲ δὴν χάζετο φωτός nor in truth was he (or it, the stone) far from the man, i.e. nearly hit him, 16.736. Poet., and mainly Ep., exc. in the compds. ἀνα-, δια-χάζομαι (qq. vv.).— οὐχ ἅζομαι, οὐχ ἅζεται (not οὐ χάζ-), shd. be written in E. Or. 1116, Alc. 326, A. Eu. 389.

genuine, true, good, Lacon. word in Ar. Lys. 91; Comp. χαϊώτερος ib. 1157; Ἀναξαγόρου τρόφιμος χαΐου Alex.Aet. 7 (Valck. for ἀρχαίου); cf. βαθυχάϊος:—also χᾱός, όν, χαοὶ οἱ ἐπάνωθεν the good men of olden time, Theoc. 7.5, ubi v. Sch., cf. χάσιος.
shepherdʼs staff, A.R. 4.972, Call. Fr. 125. (Cf. Gaulish gaiso- (Lat. gaesum, Gr. γαῖσον) ‘javelin’.)
Arist. MM 1192b18 (v.l.), Andronic.Rhod. p. 573 M.
say χαῖρε, to greet, welcome, τινα LXX To. 7.1, POxy. 1242ii35 (iii A. D.), D.L. 3.98, Lyd. Mens. 4.158; salute a god, PMag.Par. 1.1053.
greeting, salutation, Sch.rec. A. Pers. 935.
greeting, visit to a person of rank, Plb. 32.15.8; salutation addressed to a god, PMag.Par. 1.1046.

definition: χαιρετιστικός, ή, όν, Sch.rec. A. Pers. l.c.

children.definition: chervil, Anthriscus Cerefolium, only in Lat. form chaerephylon (metri grat.) Colum. 10.110; caerefolium Plin. HN 19.170.
delectation, Com. word in Ar. Ach. 4, formed after ἀλγηδών.
jovial, hilarious, Vett.Val. 18.29.
joy, BCH 50.529 ( Marathon, ii A. D.), Hsch.

definition: χαίρω, Il. 7.191, etc.; 3 pl. imper. χαιρόντων E. HF 575: impf., Ep. χαῖρον Il. 14.156, Ion. χαίρεσκον 18.259: fut. χαιρήσω 20.363, Hdt. 1.128, Ar. Pl. 64, And. 1.101, Arr. An. 5.20.6; Ep. redupl. inf. κεχᾰρησέμεν Il. 15.98; later χᾰρῶ v.l. in Apoc. 11.10: aor. ἐχαίρησα Plu. Luc. 25: pf. κεχάρηκα Ar. V. 764, part. -ηκώς Hdt. 3.42, etc., Ep. acc. κεχᾰρηότα, pl. -ότας, Il. 7.312, Hes. Fr. 77:— Med. (in same sense), χαίρομαι, noted as a barbarism in Ar. Pax 291 (v. Sch.), but found in BCH 36.622 (Perinthus, written χέρ-), Alex.Aphr. Pr. 1.20, al.: fut. χᾰρήσομαι Ps.-Luc. Philopatr. 24, ( συγ-) Plb. 30.18.1, D.S. 31.15; Dor. χαρησοῦμαι Pythag. Ep. 3.7; χᾰροῦμαι LXXZa.4.10, ( κατα-) ib. Pr. 1.26; Ep. κεχᾰρήσομαι Od. 23.266: aor. 1 part. χαιρησάμενος BGU 742 ii 3 (ii A. D.): Ep. aor.1 χήρατο Il. 14.270; ἐχ- Opp. C. 1.509, etc.; part. χηράμενος AP 7.198 ( Leon.): Ep. redupl. aor. 2, 3 pl. κεχάροντο Il. 16.600 ( χάροντο Q.S. 6.315); opt. 3 sg. and pl. κεχάροιτο, -οίατο, Od. 2.249, Il. 1.256:— Pass. (in same sense), aor. 2 ἐχάρην [ᾰ] 7.54, etc., Ep. 3 sg. χάρη 5.682, 13.609; subj. χᾰρῇς Pl. R. 606c; opt. χᾰρείη Il. 6.481; inf. χᾰρῆναι Simon. 164; part. χᾰρείς Il. 10.541, Sapph. 118, Pi. I. 6(5).10, Ar. Th. 981 (lyr.), etc.; pf. κεχάρημαι h.Bacch. 7.10, E. IA 200 (lyr.), Ar. V. 389 (anap.); part. κεχαρμένος E. Or. 1122, Tr. 529 (lyr.), Cyc. 367 (lyr.): plpf. 3 sg. and pl. κεχάρητο, -ηντο, Hes. Sc. 65, h.Cer. 458:—

children.definition: rejoice, be glad, Il. 3.111, 21.347, etc.; γραῦς ἥδε οἰνοφόρος κεχαρημένη ὧδε κάθηται IG 12(8).679 ( Scyros, ii B. C.): χ. θυμῷ Il. 7.191, al.; ἐν θυμῷ 24.491, Od. 22.411; φρεσὶν ᾗσι Il. 13.609; φρένα 6.481; χ. νόῳ to rejoice in wardly, Od. 8.78; χαίρει δέ μοι ἦτορ Il. 23.647; αὐτὰρ ἐμὸν κῆρ χ. Od. 4.260; χ. καὶ γελᾶν S. El. 1300; ἥδομαι καὶ χαίρομαι κεὐφραίνομαι Ar. Pax 291; opp. λυπεῖσθαι, A. Fr. 266.3, S. Aj. 555, etc.; opp. ἀλγεῖν, Id. Tr. 1119. —Constr.,

data.quote: γραῦς ἥδε οἰνοφόρος κεχαρημένη ὧδε κάθηται

children.definition: rejoice at, take pleasure in a thing, νίκῃ Il. 7.312; φήμῃ Od. 2.35; δώρῳ Hes. Op. 358; μόλπᾳ Sapph. 96.5 L.-P., cf. S. OT 1070, Pl. Mx. 238d, etc.: c. dat. pers., χαῖρε . . ἀνδρὶ δικαίῳ Od. 3.52; with a part. added, χάρη δʼ ἄρα οἱ προσιόντι Il. 5.682, cf. 24.706, Od. 19.463: with Preps., χαίρειν ἐπί τινι S. Fr. 926, X. Mem. 2.6.35, Cyr. 8.4.12, Isoc. 2.30, Pl. Lg. 739d, etc.; πρὸς τοῖς παιδικοῖς Eup. 327; with a part. added, ἐπʼ ἐξεργασμένοις κακοῖσι χ. E. Ba. 1040, cf. 1033: rarely ἔν τινι A. Eu. 996 (lyr.), S. Tr. 1119: also c. dat. modi, χ. γέλωτι express oneʼs joy by laughter, X. Cyr. 8.1.33.

children.label: b
children.definition: χαίρει ὑφάμμοις χωρίοις Thphr. HP 6.5.2; also ἡ κύστις χ. τῇ χολῇ Gal. 19.646.
part. added, χαίρω δέ σʼ εὐτυχοῦντα E. Rh. 390; τοὺς γὰρ εὐσεβεῖς θεοὶ θνῄσκοντας οὐ χ. Id. Hipp. 1340; χαίρω σʼ <ἐλθόντα> Id. Fr. 673 (this usage is said to be Oropian, EM 808.4).

data.quote: τοὺς γὰρ εὐσεβεῖς θεοὶ θνῄσκοντας οὐ χ.

children.label: b
children.definition: Adj., ταὐτὰ λυπεῖσθαι καὶ ταὐτὰ χαίρειν τοῖς πολλοῖς D. 18.292: c. acc. cogn., ἁπλῆν χαίρειν ἡδονήν Arist. EN 1154b26; χ. ἀνδραπόδων τινὰ χαράν Plu. Suav. 2.1091e.

data.quote: ταὐτὰ λυπεῖσθαι καὶ ταὐτὰ χαίρειν τοῖς πολλοῖς

children.definition: part., χαίρω . . τὸν μῦθον ἀκούσας I rejoice at having heard, am glad to hear, Il. 19.185, cf. 7.54, 11.73; χαίρουσιν βίοτον νήποινον ἔδοντες Od. 14.377, cf. 12.380, Hes. Op. 55; χαίρω . . κόμπον ἱείς Pi. N. 8.49; χαίρεις ὁρῶν φῶς, πατέρα δʼ οὐ χαίρειν δοκεῖς; E. Alc. 691; χαίρω φειδόμενος Ar. Pl. 247; θωπευόμενος χαίρεις Id. Eq. 1116 (lyr.), cf. Pl. Smp. 191e, etc.

data.quote: χαίρεις ὁρῶν φῶς, πατέρα δʼ οὐ χαίρειν δοκεῖς;

children.label: b
children.definition: part. pres., delight in doing, to be wont to do, χρεώμενοι χαίρουσι Hdt. 7.236, cf. S. Ph. 449, Ar. V. 764, Pl. Prt. 318d, 346c, 358a.
χαίρειν ὅττι or ὅτι . . , Od. 14.51, 526, Pi. N. 5.46; ἐχάρην καὶ ἐθρασυνάμην ὅτι ἔμαθον . . Metrod. Fr. 42; χ. οὕνεκα . . Od. 8.200.

children.label: II
children.definition: fut., οὐ χαιρήσεις thou wilt or shalt not rejoice, i.e. thou shalt not go unpunished, shalt repent it, Ar. Pl. 64; οὐ χαιρήσετον Id. Eq. 235; so οὐδέ τινʼ οἴω Τρώων χαιρήσειν Il. 20.363, cf. 15.98, Od. 2.249, Ar. V. 186; ἀλλʼ οὐδʼ ὣς Κῦρός γε χαιρήσει Hdt. 1.128; with an interrog., σὺ . . χαιρήσειν νομίζεις; Plu. Alex. 51: rarely with other tenses, ὅπως ἂν μὴ χαίρωσιν. D. 19.299; οὐκ ἐχαίρησεν Plu. Luc. 25: for a similar use of the part., v. infr. IV.2.

children.label: III
children.definition: χαῖρε, dual χαίρετον, pl. χαίρετε, as a form of greeting,

hail, welcome (esp. in the morning, acc. to D.C. 69.18, cf. Luc. Laps.), Il. 9.197, Od. 13.229, etc.; χαῖρε, ξεῖνε, παρʼ ἄμμι φιλήσεαι 1.123; strengthd., οὖλέ τε, καὶ μάλα χαῖρε, θεοὶ δέ τοι ὄλβια δοῖεν 24.402; χαῖρέ μοι Il. 23.19, cf. S. OC 1137; repeated, A. Eu. 996, 1014 (both lyr.), S. Aj. 91, etc.; χαῖρʼ ὡς μέγιστα, χαῖρε Id. Ph. 462; in greeting oneʼs native land, the sun, etc., A. Ag. 508, 22, S. Ph. 1453 (anap.).

data.quote: οὖλέ τε, καὶ μάλα χαῖρε, θεοὶ δέ τοι ὄλβια δοῖεν

children.label: b
children.definition: χαίρω, κῆρυξ Ἀχαιῶν, χαῖρε . . Answ. χαίρω I accept the greeting, A. Ag. 538; νῦν πᾶσι χαίρω, νῦν με πᾶς ἀσπάζεται I hear the word χαῖρε from all, S. OT 596: so in inf., τὸ χαίρειν dub. l. in Pl. Chrm. 164e; χαίρειν δὲ τὸν κήρυκα προὐννέπω I bid him welcome, S. Tr. 227; προσειπών τινα χ. οὐκ ἀντιπροσερρήθη X. Mem. 3.13.1; but χαίρειν τἄλλʼ ἐγώ σʼ ἐφίεμαι I bid thee have thy pleasure, S. Aj. 112.

children.label: c
children.definition: inf. alone at the beginning of letters, Κῦρος Κυαξάρῃ χαίρειν (sc. λέγει) X. Cyr. 4.5.27, cf. Theoc. 14.1; used by Alexander the Great to Phocion as a mark of respect, Duris 51J.

fare-thee-well, Od. 5.205, 13.59, 15.151; χαῖρε πόλλʼ ὦδελφέ Ar. Ra. 164; pl., χαίρετε πολλάκι Theoc. 1.144; freq. put into the mouth of the dying, S. Aj. 863, Tr. 921, Pl. Phd. 116d, etc.: hence in sepulchral inscriptions, IG 7.203, etc.

children.label: b
children.definition: χαιρέτω, χαιρόντων, have done with . . , away with . . , εἴτʼ ἐγένετο ἄνθρωπος εἴτʼ ἐστὶ δαίμων, χαιρέτω Hdt. 4.96; χαιρέτω βουλεύματα τὰ πρόσθεν E. Med. 1044, χαιρόντων πόνοι Id. HF 575; cf. Pl. Smp. 199a, Lg. 636d, 886d.

data.quote: εἴτʼ ἐγένετο ἄνθρωπος εἴτʼ ἐστὶ δαίμων, χαιρέτω

children.label: c
children.definition: ἐᾶν χαίρειν τινά or τι dismiss from oneʼs mind, put away, renounce, Hdt. 6.23, 9.41, Ar. Pl. 1187, Pl. Phd. 63e, Prt. 348a, X. An. 7.3.23, etc.; συχνὰ χ. ἐᾶν τινα Pl. Phlb. 59b; ἐλευθερίαν μακρὰ χ. ἐᾶν Luc. Apol. 3; μακρὰ χ. εἰποῦσα Ael. VH 12.1; πόλλα μοι τὰν Πωλυανάκτιδα παῖδα χαίρην Sapph. 86; τὴν Κύπριν πόλλʼ ἐγὼ χαίρειν λέγω E. Hipp. 113, cf. 1059, Pl. Tht. 188a; χ. κελεύων πολλὰ τοὺς Ἀχαρνέας Ar. Ach. 200; εἰπεῖν χαίρειν τινά Ath.Mitt. 56.131 (Milet., Hellenistic), cf. Luc. Dem.Enc. 50; χαίρειν προσαγορεύειν Ar. Pl. 322 (metaph. in Pl. Lg. 771a); χαίρειν προσειπεῖν Eup. 308: less freq. c. dat. pers. (never with ἐᾶν χ.) , πολλὰ χαίρειν ξυμφοραῖς καταξιῶ A. Ag. 572 (nisi leg. ξυμφοράς) ; φράσαι . . χαίρειν Ἀθηναίοισι Ar. Nu. 609 (troch.); πολλὰ εἰπόντα χ. τῷ ἀληθεῖ Pl. Phdr. 272e, cf. Phd. 64c, R. 406d, X. HG 4.1.31 (codd., fort. ἀλλήλους), Jul. ad Them. 255a (2).

data.quote: πόλλα μοι τὰν Πωλυανάκτιδα παῖδα χαίρην
τὴν Κύπριν πόλλʼ ἐγὼ χαίρειν λέγω

children.definition: be of good cheer, Od. 8.408; at meals, 4.60, 18.122; χαῖρε, γύναι, φιλότητι good luck be on our union, 11.248; εὐχωλῇς χαίρετε 13.358: χαῖρε ἀοιδῇ h.Hom. 9.7.

children.label: IV
children.definition: part. χαίρων glad, joyful, Il. 1.446, etc.; χαίροντα φίλην ἐς πατρίδʼ ἔπεμπον εἰς Ἰθάκην Od. 19.461; χαίροντι φέρειν . . χαίρων 17.83; λυπούμενοι καὶ χαίροντες in sorrow and in joy, Arist. Rh. 1356a16: also pf. part. κεχαρηκώς Hdt. 3.27, 42, etc.

data.quote: χαίροντα φίλην ἐς πατρίδʼ ἔπεμπον εἰς Ἰθάκην

children.definition: safe and sound, with impunity, χαίροντα ἀπαλλάσσειν ib. 69, cf. 9.106, D. 24.153; more freq. with a neg., οὐ χαίρων to oneʼs cost, οὐ χαίροντες γέλωτα ἐμὲ θήσεσθε Hdt. 3.29; οὔ τι χαίρων . . ἐρεῖς S. OT 363, cf. Ant. 759, Ph. 1299, E. Med. 398, Ar. Ach. 563, Pl. Grg. 510d; οὐ γὰρ . . χαίρων τις . . τοὐμὸν ἀλγυνεῖ κέαρ Eup. 90; οὔτε χαίροντες ἂν ἀπαλλάζαιτε X. An. 5.6.32; also οὔτι χαιρήσων γε σύ Ar. V. 186; cf. supr. II.

data.quote: οὐ γὰρ . . χαίρων τις . . τοὐμὸν ἀλγυνεῖ κέαρ

children.definition: σὺ δέ μοι χαίρων ἀφίκοιο fare-thee- well, and mayʼst thou arrive, Od. 15.128, cf. Theoc. 2.163; χαίροισʼ ἔρχεο go thy way rejoicing, Sapph. 94.7 L.-P.; ἀλλʼ ἑρπέτω χαίρουσα let her go with a benison, S. Tr. 819; χαίρων ἴθι fare-thee- well, E. Alc. 813, Ph. 921; χαίρουσα . . στεῖχε Id. Hipp. 1440.
τὸ χαῖρον τῆς ψυχῆς Plu. Sanit. 2.136c, Suav. 1089e.

children.label: V
children.definition: αἵρεσις, Serapio in Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(4).230, Ptol. Tetr. 51, Vett.Val. 63.6, Man. 2.348. (Cf. Skt. háryati ‘take pleasure in’, Umbr. heriest ‘will wish’, Lat. horior.)

definition: χαιτέεις, εσσα, εν, Old Ionic for χαιτήεις, Semon. 7.57.

children.definition: loose, flowing hair, ζανθὴν ἀπεκείρατο χαίτην Il. 23.141; τίλλοντό τε χαίτας Od. 10.567, cf. S. Aj. 634 (lyr.): χαίταν ἐλαίᾳ . . στεφανωσάμενον B. 10.28; pl., of a single person, χαίτας πεξαμένη Il. 14.175, cf. 10.15, Pi. N. 1.14, B. 16.105, etc.; χαίτᾰς ( Dor. acc.) ὑπὲρ κεφαλῆς Tyrt. 1.39 Diehl; used esp. of back hair, acc.to Ruf. Onom. 14.
mane, θαλερὴ δʼ ἐμιαίνετο χαίτη Il. 17.439, cf. 19.405; ἀμφὶ δὲ χαῖται ὤμοις ἀΐσσονται 6.509, cf. X. Eq. 5.5, 7.1, Plu. Pel. 22.

Hom., of a lionʼs mane, E. Ph. 1121; ὅσα χαίτην ἔχει, ὥσπερ λέων, opp. ὅσα λοφιὰν ἔχει, ὥσπερ ἵππος, Arist. HA 498b28, cf. PA 658a31: but metaph., φρίξας λοφιᾶς λασιαύχενα χαίταν, of Aeschylus, Ar. Ra. 822 (hex.).

children.label: b
children.definition: ὀξυβελεῖς χ., of a hedgehogʼs spines, Emp. 83.2.
crest of a helmet, Plu. Alex. 16.

foliage, Call. Del. 81: pl., Theoc. 6.16, Anacreont. 17/18.12; also βύβλος . . ἐπʼ ἄκρῳ χαίτην ἔχουσα Str. 17.1.15. (Ambraciot word acc. to AB 1095: not in Prose of human hair; cf. Avest. gaēsa- ‘curly hair’.)
with long flowing hair, epith. of Apollo, Pi. P. 9.5, cf. AP 6.234 ( Eryc.).
with a long mane, of the horse, Phoc. 3, A.R. 2.1237; of bears, shaggy, Opp. H. 5.38.
thick-leaved, καλάμινθος Nic. Th. 60; cf. χαιτέεις.
plume, κράνους A. Th. 385.

definition: χάκωμα, misspelling of χάλκωμα, JHS 32.159 ( Pisidia).

children.definition: mat or pallet, PTeb. 414.13 (ii A. D.), POxy. 646 (ii A. D.), etc., cf. χάλανδρον; also written χαλάτριον PLond. 5.1714.32 (vi A. D.).

hail (cf. Pl. Ti. 59e, Arist. Mu. 394b1), ὄμβρον . . ἠὲ χάλαζαν ἢ νιφετόν Il. 10.6, cf. 15.170, Apoc. 8.7, etc.: pl., X. Oec. 5.18, Pl. Smp. 188b, R. 397a; χ. στρογγύλαι hailstones, Ar. Nu. 1127 (troch.); ἀπὸ τῶν χαλαζῶν . . ἄπαγε σεαυτόν Id. Ra. 852: metaph., any pelting shower, ὀμβρία χ. S. OC 1503; χ. αἵματος Pi. I. 7(6).27.

children.label: II
children.definition: any small knot like a hailstone,
pimple or tubercle in the flesh of swine, Arist. HA 603b18, Pr. 963b34, Androsth. ap. Ath. 3.93c.
small cyst, such as grows on the eyelid, Gal. 19.437, Poll. 4.198, etc.
a knot or hard lump; in an egg, Arist. HA 560a28; in coal, Thphr. Sign. 25; in ivory, Philostr. VA 2.13; λίθοι χαλάζης crystals, I Enoch 14.9,10. (Cf. Sloven. žled, Ukr. oželeda ‘sleet, ice’.)

children.label: II
children.definition: knotty, φηγός Orph. A. 763.
hail, Luc. Bis Acc. 2: metaph., fall thick as hail, Com.Adesp. 314.

children.label: II
children.definition: to have pimples or tubercles, Ar. Eq. 381; χαλαζῶσαι [ὕες] Arist. HA 603b21.
hurling abuse as thick as hail, τάφος, of Hipponax, AP 7.405 ( Phil.).
like hail, φόνος χ. blood thick as hail (cf. χάλαζα I fin.), Pi. I. 5(4).50; συρμός AP 6.221 ( Leon.); ὀϊστοί Nonn. D. 18.232.

children.label: II
children.definition: σκορπίος χ. a scorpion whose sting causes an icy chill, Nic. Th. 13.
Plin. HN 37.189.
suffer from χάλαζαι II.2, Aët. 7.83.
Dim. of χάλαζα II.2, Cels. 7.7.3, Gal. 10.1019, Paul.Aeg. 3.22.

children.label: II
children.definition: trichinosis, in pigs, Archig. ap. Aët. 13.120.
full of knots or clots, σπέρμα Steph. in Hp. 2.479D.

children.label: II
children.definition: god of hail, at Cyzicus, JHS 24.21; of Apollo at Thebes, Procl. ap. Phot. Bibl. p.321 B.

children.label: III
children.definition: Subst., name of a precious stone, resembling a hailstone, Orph. L. 758, cf. χαλαζίας.
shower hail, AP 5.63 ( Asclep.).
showering hail, νέφη Plu. Vitios. 2.499f.
smite with hail, in Pass., Thphr. CP 5.8.3, HP 4.14.1.
damage by hailstorm, Thphr. CP 5.8.2.
to be hailed upon, Gloss.
hail-guard, one who averts hail by magical rites, Sen. QN 4.6, Plu. QConv. 2.700f.
like hail, πάγος ἀέρος Plu. Fac.lun. 2.922c.

children.label: b
children.definition: granular, σπερματα Arist. HA 582a30, cf. Ruf. Anat. 57; containing granules, of urinary sediment, Hp. Coac. 569; of sputum, Aret. SD 1.12.
bringing hail, ἄνεμοι Arist. Mete. 365a1, cf. 364b22, Vett.Val. 6.4, Gp. 1.12.18; ζῴδιον (viz. Aries) Cat.Cod.Astr. 4.152.

children.label: II
children.definition: pimply, of the tongue, Hp. Epid. 4.10; of pigs, measly, Arist. HA 603b16.
pimpliness, Gal. 14.770.
χαλάω 1.4, ῥυτὰ χαλαίνοντες Hes. Sc. 308.

definition: χαλαίπους, ὁ, ἡ, neut. πουν, gen. ποδος:—

children.definition: with loose, trailing feet, halting, Ἥφαιστος Nic. Th. 458; vv.ll. χωλοίπους, κυλλόπους.
suds in which clothes have been washed, Cratin. 452, cj. in Polem.Hist. 83 ( χαμαὶ ῥυπῶ codd. Macr.).

slack, loose, δέρματα Hp. Aph. 5.71; ὑποδήματα Ar. Th. 263; ἁλύσεις Th. 2.76; χαλινός X. Eq. 10.3, cf. 7.1; θῶραξ ib. 12.1; χ. κοτυληδών loose, supple joint, Ar. V. 1495 (anap.); χ. κνήμη, opp. σκληρά, X. Eq. 7.6; χ. ἁρμονίαι loose, languid, effeminate music, Pl. R. 398e; χαλαρωτέραν . . ἐποίησε χορδαῖς δώδεκα (sc. τὴν μουσικήν) Pherecr. 145.5; χ. πόροι relaxed, open pores, Arist. HA 514a32; τὸ χ., = χαλαρότης, Anaximen. 1. Adv. -ρῶς Hp. Fract. 16; χ. ἐνηρμόσθαι, δεδέσθαι, Plb. 34.3.5, Gp. 5.8.4.
slackness, looseness, X. Eq. 9.9, 10.13, 16, Gal. 18(2).87.
to be relaxed in tension, Erot. s.v. σφυγμοί.

slackening, loosening, of bandages, Hp. Fract. 10 (pl.); τῇ χ. τε καὶ ἀνέσει Pl. R. 590b; relaxation, τοῦ ῥοώδους χαλάσεως δεομένου Gal. Sect.Intr. 7; τῶν στεγνῶν ib. 6; but χ. νόσου remission, opp. ἐπίδοσις, Id. 19.190.
free play of the parts of a whole, Plot. 4.4.45; τῇ χαλάσει εἰδοποιηθῆναι Dam. Pr. 47.
lowering by means of pulleys, κιόνων University of Egypt, Faculty of Arts Bulletin 3(2).58.
slackened condition, relaxation, ἀναπνοὴ καὶ χ. Plu. Sanit. 2.133d, cf. Luc. Asin. 9; lack of elasticity, Ph. Bel. 58.8, 65.50; low tension of blood-vessels, Orib. 7.19.6.
gap in the line of battle, Plb. 18.30.8; σύμμετρον ἔχειν χ. to be packed not too tightly, Plu. Aem. 32.
slit, Ruf. Anat. 59, Gal. 4.733; χ. ποιῶν ἐν τῇ ὑποτομῇ IG 7.3073.114 ( Lebad., ii B. C.).
baulk or footpath on the edge of arable land, PLille 2.16 (iii B. C.), PGiss. 36.17 (ii B. C.), PLond. 3.881.21 (ii B. C.), etc.
dislocation, ἄρθρων Dsc. 1.109 (pl.).
congenital hernia, Vett.Val. 161.19 (pl.).
free play (cf. foreg. 2) of a joint, Erot. s.v. πλοώδης.
slight slackening in a rope, Hero Aut. 19.3.
Dsc. 1.109 (pl., v.l.), Herod.Med. ap. Orib. 10.8.10, Philum. ap. eund. 45.29.2.
one must relax, Herod.Med. in Rh.Mus. 58.91, Gal. Sect.Intr. 7.
ropes for letting down a portcullis, opp. ἀνασπαστήρια, App. BC 4.78: cf. σχαστήρια.
fit for slackening or making supple, ἔλαιον σωμάτων χ. Sch. Il. 23.281, cf. Plu. QConv. 2.658e.
laxative, Gal. Sect.Intr. 7; ὁ χ. τρόπος τῆς ἐπιμελείας S.E. P. 2.240.
festoon, LXX 2 Ch. 3.5, 16; chain as ornament, PSI 2.183.6 (v A. D.).
relaxed, dub. in PRyl. 198 Intr. (iii A. D.).

of, from Chalastra on the Thermaic Gulf:— τὸ Χαλαστραῖον (sc. νίτρον) prob. a fine kind of soda, found in a lake near that place, used with lye or soap for purposes of cleansing, Pl. R. 430a, Plu. Sanit. 2.134e (pl.); ῥύμματι καὶ νίτρῳ Χαλαστραίῳ Alciphr. 3.61, cf. Plin. HN 31.115.— Χαλεστραίου is v.l. in Pl. l.c., Χαλέστρη is found in Hdt. 7.123.
to be loose, of joints, Dsc. 1.112; get loose, of a bandage, Heliod. ap. Orib. 48.33.5; relax in tension, Porph. in Harm. p.294 W., Herm. in Phdr. p.130A.
χαλατριόομαι, to be furnished with mats, PLond. 3.1164 h. 7 (iii A. D.).

definition: χαλάω, A. Eu. 219, etc., Ep. 3 pl. χαλόωσιν Opp. H. 2.451; Aeol. 3 pl. χόλαισι Alc. 18.9 codd. Heraclit.: fut. χᾰλάσω [λᾰ] Hp. Aër. 8, Epid. 7.80: aor. ἐχάλᾰσα A. Pr. 177 (anap.), Hp. Epid. 7.23, etc.; Ep. χάλασσα h.Ap. 6, pl. subj. χαλάσσομεν Alc. Supp. 23.10; Dor. part. χᾰλάξαις Pi. P. 1.6; 3 sg. fut. or aor. subj. χαλάξει (dub. sens.) Berl.Sitzb. 1927.164 ( Cyrene):— Med., Ep. aor. χαλάσαντο A.R. 2.1264:— Pass., aor. ἐχαλάσθην, subj. χᾰλασθῇ A. Pr. 991, Pl. Phd. 86c: pf. κεχάλασμαι AP 9.297 (Antip.), App. Mith. 74, Plot. 4.3.16: plpf. ἐκεχάλαστο Aristid. 1.315J.

children.label: I
children.definition: slacken, loosen, χ. βιόν, τόξα, unstring the bow, h.Ap. 6, h.Hom. 27.12; χ. τὰ νεῦρα, opp. συντείνειν, Pl. Phd. 98d; χ. τὸν πόδα, of a ship, v. πούς II.2: metaph., τὰ τῆς πολιτείας χ., opp. ἐπιτείνειν, Plu. Monarch. 2.827b:— Pass., opp. ἐπιτείνεσθαι, Pl. Phd. 86c, 94c; χαλᾶσθαι καὶ διαφθείρεσθαι Id. Lg. 653c; χαλᾶσθαι ὑπὸ τῆς ἡδονῆς Porph. Marc. 7.

let down, let fall, πτέρυγα χαλάξαις Pi. l.c.; χαλάσας ὀλίγον τὸ μέτωπον having unbent the brow, Ar. V. 655 (anap.); μαστοὺς χάλασον, says the Cyclops to his ewe, E. Cyc. 55 (lyr.); κράββατον, δίκτυα χ., Ev.Marc. 2.4, Ev.Luc. 5.5; τὴν ἱερὰν ἄγκυραν Suid.; dip in a liquid, εἰς αἷμα PMag.Par. 1.2886; soak, PHolm. 14.33:— Med., ἱστὸν χαλάσαντο lowered it, A.R. 2.1264.
let loose, release, τινὰ ἐκ δεσμῶν A. Pr. 177 (anap.); abs., let go, slacken oneʼs hold, μηδαμῇ χάλα ib. 58.
ἡνίας χ. slacken the reins, esp. in metaph. sense, χ. τὰς ἡνίας τοῖς λόγοις Pl. Prt. 338a, cf. E. Fr. 409.
κλῇθρα χ. loose the bars or bolts, i.e. undo or open the door, S. Ant. 1187, E. Hipp. 808; κλῇδας Id. Med. 1314; χ. τοὺς μοχλούς Ar. Lys. 310; but also πύλας μοχλοῖς χαλᾶτε A. Ch. 879.

loosen or undo things drawn tightly together, χ. κρεμαστὴν ἀρτάνην S. OT 1266; χ. πᾶν κάλυμμʼ ἀπʼ ὀφθαλμῶν Id. El. 1468; χ. δεσμά E. Andr. 577; ἀσκόν Id. Cyc. 161; τὸ στόμα X. Eq. 6.8:— Pass., τὰ χαλώμενα ὅπλα Hp. Art. 43; πρὶν ἂν χαλασθῇ δεσμά A. Pr. 991.
ὑγρὰ χ. Hp. Prorrh. 1.99, cf. Coac. 20; ἢν αἱ μῆτραι μὴ χαλάσωσι τὰ ἐπιμήνια Id. Mul. 1.61.

data.quote: ἢν αἱ μῆτραι μὴ χαλάσωσι τὰ ἐπιμήνια

children.definition: τὴν ὀργήν χ. let it go, Ar. V. 727 (anap.); χ. [τὸν νόον] ἐς ὄψιν τινός Ti.Locr. 104c; χ. ἐπιθυμίαν Plu. Sanit. 2.133a; τὸ βαρὺ καὶ ἀμειδές Alciphr. 3.3; remit, μήτε τῆς προνοίας χαλώσης τὴν . . ὑπεροχήν Procl. Inst. 122; τὸ ἀεὶ ταῦτα οὕτως ἔχειν ἐχάλασαν relaxed the strict principle that . . Pl. Sph. 242e:— Pass., to be softened, λίθος εἰς ὑγρότητα κεχαλασμένος Callistr. Stat. 5; also κεχαλάσθαι εἰς τὸ αὐτεξούσιον to have free play, opp. συντετάχθαι, Plot. 4.3.16.

data.quote: μήτε τῆς προνοίας χαλώσης τὴν . . ὑπεροχήν

children.label: II
children.definition: become slack or loose, opp. συντείνω, Pl. Phd. 98d; χόλαισιν ἄγκυρραι Alc. 18.9 (s. v.l.); ζῶναι χαλῶσι E. Ba. 935; πύλαι χαλῷσαι open gates, X. Cyr. 7.5.29: metaph. c. gen., have a remission of, χαλάσσομεν τὰς θυμοβόρω λύας Alc. Supp. 23.10; τί χαλᾷ μανιῶν; A. Pr. 1057 (anap.); (also abs., S. OC 203 (lyr.), 840); relax, φρονήματος χ. E. Fr. 716; τῆς ὀργῆς Ar. Av. 383 (troch.); [ τὸ ὂν] χαλάσαν τῆς τοῦ ἑνὸς ἁπλότητος Dam. Pr. 13.

data.quote: τὸ ὂν] χαλάσαν τῆς τοῦ ἑνὸς ἁπλότητος

children.definition: χ. τινι give way or yield to any one, be indulgent to him, εἰ τοῖσιν . . κτείνουσιν ἀλλήλους χαλᾷς A. Eu. 219; χάλα τοκεῦσιν E. Hec. 403; with gen. add., μοι τῆς ἀρχῆς χάλασον Pl. Men. 86e, cf. Plu. Lyc. 7: abs., give way, εἴκειν ὁδοῦ χαλῶντα τοῖς κακίοσιν E. Ion 637.
grow slack or weak, ἐπειδὰν αἱ ἐπιθυμίαι παύσωνται κατατείνουσαι καὶ χαλάσωσι Id. R. 329c; abate, χαλάσει ὁ παγετός Hp. Aër. 8; ὀδύνη Id. Acut. 16.

data.quote: ἐπειδὰν αἱ ἐπιθυμίαι παύσωνται κατατείνουσαι καὶ χαλάσωσι

children.definition: the resinous juice of all-heal, Ferula galbaniflua (v. πάνακες), Thphr. HP 9.1.2, 9.7.2, Nic. Th. 52, LXX Ex. 30.34, Si. 24.15, Dsc. 3.83, Plu. QPlat. 2.1009f. (Hebr. ḥelbenāh.)
of or from χαλβάνη, ῥίζα Nic. Th. 938: as Subst., Androm. ap. Gal. 14.41.
of or from χαλβάνη, ῥίζα Nic. Al. 555.
follow the Chaldaean fashion or creed, Ph. 1.581, 2.11.
Chaldaean, Hdt. 3.155, S. Fr. 638, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: astrologer, Arist. Fr. 35, Cic. Div. 1.1.2, Phld. Rh. 1.42S., Gem. 2.5 (since the Chaldaeans were given to astrology, cf. Hdt. 1.181, Arr. An. 7.17.1, etc.):— Χαλδαία (sc. γῆ), ἡ, Chaldaea, St.Byz., Ptol. Geog. 5.19:— Χαλδαϊκός, ή, όν, Chaldaean, γράμματα Ath. 12.529f; ἱστορίαι, title of work by Berosus, J. AJ 10.11.1, cf. Ap. 1.20; μέθοδος, i.e. astrology, S.E. M. 5.43 (so -κή alone, ib. 45); ἐπιτηδεύματα Dam. ap. Suid. s.v. Χαλδαϊκοῖς: Comp. -ώτερος Id. Pr. 206. Adv. -κῶς ib. 183:— Χαλδαϊστί, Adv. in the Chaldaean language, LXX Da. 2.26, Ph. 2.546.

definition: χαλεπαίνω, Il. 14.399, etc.: fut. -ᾰνῶ Pl. Tht. 161a, Men. Sam. 204: aor.1 ἐχαλέπηνα Isoc. 4.102, etc.; subj. χαλεπήνῃ Il. 16.386; inf. -ῆναι 18.108:— Pass., aor. ἐχαλεπάνθην, v. infr. II: ( χαλεπός):—

children.definition: to be severe, sore, grievous, μέγα βρέμεται χαλεπαίνων [ἄνεμος] Il. 14.399; εἰ καὶ μάλα περ χαλεπαίνοι [ὥρη χειμερίη] Od. 5.485.

to be violent, angry, ὅτε τις πρότερος χαλεπήνῃ Il. 19.183, cf. Ar. Ra. 1020 (anap.), Th. 3.82, 8.92, Pl. R. 426e, etc.; display or portray anger, ἀληθινώτατα Arist. Po. 1455a31: c. dat., to be angry with . . , Ζεὺς ὅτε δή ῥʼ ἄνδρεσσι κοτεσσάμενος χαλεπήνῃ Il. 16.386, cf. Od. 5.147, 16.114, 19.83; χ. τῷ ποταμῷ Hdt. 1.189, cf. Pl. Phd. 116c, X. An. 1.4.12, etc.; αἱ [κύνες] τοῖς λίθοις, οἷς ἂν βληθῶσι, χαλεπαίνουσι Pl. R. 469e: folld. by a Prep., χ. ἐπί τινι to be angry at a thing, Od. 18.415; πρός τι Th. 2.22, 59; πρός τινα X. Mem. 2.2.1: c. dupl. dat. pers. et rei, χ. τινὶ τοῖς εἰρημένοις to be angry with him for his words, Id. An. 5.5.24: rarely, c. gen. causae, ὧν ἐμοὶ χαλεπαίνετε, τούτων τοῖς θεοῖς χάριν εἰδέναι ib. 7.6.32; also χ. ὑπέρ τινος Luc. Ind. 25: folld. by a conjunction, χ. ὅτι . . X. An. 1.5.14; χαλ. εἰ . . Plu. Cam. 8, etc.

data.quote: Ζεὺς ὅτε δή ῥʼ ἄνδρεσσι κοτεσσάμενος χαλεπήνῃ
αἱ [κύνες] τοῖς λίθοις, οἷς ἂν βληθῶσι, χαλεπαίνουσι

children.definition: to be irritated, Aret. SD 2.11.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., to be embittered or provoked, χαλεπανθῆναί τινι, ὅτι . . against one, X. An. 4.6.2, Cyr. 3.1.38; πρὸς ἀλλήλους ib. 5.2.18.

children.label: III
children.definition: Pass., to be judged or treated harshly, ἐλεεῖσθαι . . μᾶλλον εἰκός ἐστί που . . ἢ χαλεπαίνεσθαι Pl. R. 337a.—Never used in Trag.

data.quote: ἐλεεῖσθαι . . μᾶλλον εἰκός ἐστί που . . ἢ χαλεπαίνεσθαι

children.definition: χαλεπός, ἄεθλον Mimn. 11.3.
difficult ( ὃ ἂν μὴ ῥᾴδιον ᾖ ἀλλὰ διὰ πολλῶν πραγμάτων γίγνηται Pl. Prt. 341d: opp. ῥᾴδιος, Arist. Rh. 1363a24, in various relations):

data.quote: ὃ ἂν μὴ ῥᾴδιον ᾖ ἀλλὰ διὰ πολλῶν πραγμάτων γίγνηται

children.label: I
children.definition: hard to bear, painful, grievous (so freq. in Hom.), κεραυνός Il. 14.417; θύελλα 21.335; ἄνεμοι Od. 12.286; πόνος 23.250; ἄλγος, πένθος, 2.193, 6.169; γῆρας Il. 8.103; ἄλη Od. 10.464; χαλεπώτερος ἄεθλος Hes. Th. 800; ἄλλα τῶν κατεχόντων πρηγμάτων -ώτερα Hdt. 6.40; χ. πνεῦμα A. Supp. 166 (lyr.); δύα Id. Th. 228 (lyr.); χαλεπώτατα [πράγματα] S. Tr. 1273 (anap.); συμφορά E. Hipp. 768 (lyr.); νόσος, πλάνη, etc., X. Smp. 4.37, Pl. Sph. 245e ( Comp.), etc.; ἡ ἐσβολὴ αὕτη -ωτάτη τοῖς Ἀθηναίοις ἐγένετο Th. 3.26; [ θώρακες] δύσφοροι καὶ χ., of ill-fitting cuirasses, X. Mem. 3.10.13: τὸ χ. τοῦ πνεύματος the severity of the wind, Id. An. 4.5.4; τὰ χ. hardships, opp. τὰ τερπνά, Id. Mem. 2.1.23, etc.; τερπνῶν χαλεπῶν τε κρίσις Pi. Fr. 131, cf. Plot. 5.9.14: Comp., more unpleasant, Jul. Or. 6.202c.

data.quote: ἡ ἐσβολὴ αὕτη -ωτάτη τοῖς Ἀθηναίοις ἐγένετο

children.definition: hard to do or deal with, difficult, irksome, -ώτατον ἔργον ἁπάντων Ar. Eq. 516 (anap.); cf. Th. 3.59 ( Sup.), etc.; χαλεπὰ τὰ καλά prov. ap. Pl. Hp.Ma. 304e, al., attributed to Solon by Sch. ad loc.; χαλεπὸν ὁ βίος X. Mem. 2.9.1, cf. Pl. Plt. 299e: c. inf. Act. or Med., χαλεπή τοι ἐγὼ μένος ἀντιφέρεσθαι, = χαλεπόν ἐστί μοι ἀντιφέρεσθαί σοι, Il. 21.482; χαλεποὶ δὲ θεοὶ φαίνεσθαι ἐναργεῖς 20.131; χαλεπὸν δέ τʼ ὀρύσσειν [τὸ μῶλυ] Od. 10.305; χ. προϊδέσθαι καπρός Hes. Sc. 386; χ. ἔρις ἀνθρώποις ὁμιλεῖν κρεσσόνων Pi. N. 10.72; χ. προσπολεμεῖν Isoc. 4.138, cf. Th. 7.51 ( Comp.); χ. συγγενέσθαι, εὑρεῖν, γενέσθαι, Pl. R. 330c, 412b, 502c; χ. πάσχειν Id. Cri. 49b ( Comp.): also c. inf. Pass., χαλεπὸς διαγνωσθῆναι καὶ δειχθῆναι Antipho 2.1.1, cf. Th. 3.94, etc.; χαλεπὸν ληφθῆναι ὁ τόπος Arist. Ph. 212a8; χαλεπόν [ἐστι] c. inf., ʼtis hard, difficult to do, Od. 4.651; c. acc. et inf., ʼtis difficult for one to do . . , Il. 16.620, Od. 20.313: c. dat. et inf., Il. 21.184, Od. 11.156.
dangerous, λιμένες 19.189; θάλασσα Th. 4.24; χ. τὰ παρόντα X. An. 3.2.2.

difficult, rugged, χωρία χ. καὶ πετρώδη Th. 4.9; ὁδός Id. 5.58, Pl. R. 328e; χ. . . καὶ προσάντης . . ὁδός ἐστιν Anaxandr. 56; πρόσοδοι X. An. 5.2.3; πορεία ib. 5.6.10; σταθμός ib. 4.5.3; χωρίον -ώτατον a place most difficult to take, ib. 4.8.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: hard to deal with, cruel, harsh, stern (opp. πρᾷος, Pl. R. 493b ( Sup.), Arist. EN 1126a26), βασιλεύς, δαίμων, Od. 2.232, 19.201; χαλεποί τε καὶ ἄγριοι 8.575; -ώτερος a more bitter enemy, Th. 3.40; -ώτατοι most difficult to deal with, most dangerous or troublesome, ib. 42, cf. 7.21; -ώτεροι πάροικοι Id. 3.113; χαλεπόν γε θυγάτηρ κτῆμα Men. 18: c. dat. pers., cruel or harsh towards one, Od. 17.388; τοῖς ξυμπροθυμηθεῖσι τὸν ἔκπλουν Th. 8.1, etc.; πρὸς τοὺς πολεμίους, τοὺς ἀγνῶτας, Pl. R. 375c, Arist. Pol. 1328a8 (also πρὸς τοὺς δρόμους X. Cyn. 5.17); ἐπὶ νύμφαις ἀλλοτρίαις Theoc. 22.145.

children.label: b
children.definition: χαλεπῷ ἠνίπαπε μύθῳ Il. 2.245, etc.; ἐρεθιζέμεν αἰεὶ μύθοισιν χ. Od. 17.395; χ. ὀνείδεα, ὁμοκλαί, Il. 3.438, Od. 17.189; φῆμις 14.239; μῆνις Il. 5.178.

children.label: c
children.definition: ἦν τὸ δίκαιον φυλάσσων χ. Hdt. 1.100, cf. Pl. Criti. 107d, And. 4.36; also χ. ἀρχή Th. 1.77; τιμωρία Pl. Ap. 39c ( Comp.); νόμοι Id. Hp.Mi. 372a ( Comp.), D. 21.44, 35.50.

children.label: d
children.definition: savage, fierce, κύνες X. An. 5.8.24, Cyn. 10.23; of bees, Arist. HA 624b30 ( Comp.); [ θηρία] χ. τὰς φύσεις Pl. Plt. 274b.
ill-tempered, testy, χ. ὢν καὶ δύσκολος Ar. V. 942, cf. Isoc. 19.26; ὀργὴν χ. Hdt. 3.131; χαλεπῇ τῇ χειρί with a rough hand, Ar. Lys. 1116.
hurtful to the soil, Thphr. HP 8.9.3 ( Sup.).

children.label: B
children.definition: Adv. -πῶς hardly, with difficulty, διαγνῶναι χ. ἦν ἄνδρα ἕκαστον Il. 7.424; χ. δέ σʼ ἔολπα τὸ ῥέξειν 20.186; χ. κε φύγοις κακόν Hes. Op. 684; χ. ὀργὰς μεταβάλλουσιν E. Med. 121 (anap.); χ. γνῶναι Antipho 3.2.1; τὰ τοῖς ἄλλοις χ. εὑρημένα ῥᾳδίως μανθάνειν Isoc. 1.18, cf. 44; οὐ or μὴ χ. without much ado, Th. 1.2, 7.81, etc.

data.quote: χ. δέ σʼ ἔολπα τὸ ῥέξειν
τὰ τοῖς ἄλλοις χ. εὑρημένα ῥᾳδίως μανθάνειν

children.definition: hardly, scarcely, δοκέω . . χ. ἂν Ἕλληνας Πέρσῃσι μάχεσθαι Hdt. 7.103; χ. παρὰ τοῖς ἐχθροῖς εὑρεθήσεται Lys. 29.2; χ. ἂν πείσαιμι Pl. Phd. 84d.

data.quote: δοκέω . . χ. ἂν Ἕλληνας Πέρσῃσι μάχεσθαι

children.definition: χ. ἔχει, = χαλεπόν ἐστι, Th. 3.53: c. acc. et inf., X. HG 7.4.6.
painfully, miserably, -ώτερον ζῆν Pl. R. 579d; ἐν τοῖς -ώτατα διῆγον Th. 7.71.

children.label: II
children.definition: angrily, cruelly, harshly, χ. τιμωρεῖσθαι Id. 3.46; ἀποκρίνασθαι Id. 5.42, cf. E. Hipp. 203 (anap.), Ar. Pl. 60, Pl. Phdr. 269b; χ. φέρειν τι take it ill, Th. 2.16, Pl. R. 330a, etc.; also χ. ἔφερον τῷ πολέμῳ, τοῖς πράγμασιν, X. HG 5.1.29, An. 1.3.3; ἐπὶ τῇ πολιορκίᾳ Id. HG 7.4.21, cf. D.H. 3.50; also χ. φέρειν τινός Th. 2.62; also χ. λαμβάνεσθαι τοῦ παιδός Hdt. 2.121.δʹ; χ. λαμβάνειν περί τινος Th. 6.61; of the laws (cf. supr. II.1 c), χ. προστάττειν Pl. Lg. 925d.

χ. ἔχειν to be angry, X. An. 6.4.16, etc.; τινι with one, Id. HG 1.5.16; πρὸς τοὺς λόγους Isoc. 3.3, cf. 51; χ. ἔχειν τισὶν ἐπί τινι with persons for a thing, D. 20.135, cf. Plu. Cic. 43; χ. διακεῖσθαι πρὸς ἅπαντας Isoc. Ep. 7.5; χ. πρὸς φιλοσοφίαν διακεῖσθαι Pl. R. 500b; χ. πρὸς ἡμᾶς διετέθησαν Isoc. 8.79; ἐπί τινι χ. διατεθείς Plu. Per. 36.

children.label: b
children.definition: χ. ἔχειν, also, to be in a bad way, χ. ἔχω ὑπὸ τοῦ πότου Pl. Smp. 176a, cf. Tht. 142b.—
Comp. χαλεπώτερον ( Th. 1.77, 7.50, Pl. Phd. 94d, etc.) we have -ωτέρως Th. 2.50, 8.40, Thphr. HP 6.7.1: Sup. -ώτατα Th. 7.71, 8.95, Pl. R. 579d, etc.
difficulty, ruggedness, τῶν χωρίων Th. 4.12, 33: metaph. in pl., μεγάλας ἔχουσιν αἱ σύντομοι [ὁδοὶ] χαλεπότητας Jul. Or. 7.225c.
difficulty, of understanding, Arist. APo. 93b34.

children.label: II
children.definition: harshness, severity, opp. ῥᾳστώνη, Pl. Criti. 107c, Lg. 902c; ἡ τοῦ σοφιστοῦ χ. Id. Sph. 254a; τρόπων χ. Id. Lg. 929d; τῶν πολιτειῶν Isoc. 4.142; abs., Th. 1.84, Isoc. 2.24, etc.; of the Lacedaemonians, Id. 12.90; μετὰ χαλεπότητος ἀκροᾶσθαι Id. 15.20; of the laws of Draco, Arist. Pol. 1274b17: pl., opp. πραότητες, Isoc. 5.116.
ill-temper, vice, of a horse, X. Eq. 3.10.

definition: χαλεπτύς, ύος, ἡ, Ion. for foreg., Hsch.
χαλέπτω, poet. aor. χάλεψα Dosiad. Ara 13:— Med. and Pass., v. infr. ΙΙ:—

children.definition: oppress, crush, εἴρεσθαι δὲ θεῶν ὅστις σε χαλέπτει Od. 4.423; ῥέα δὲ βριάοντα χαλέπτει Hes. Op. 5; πιέζειν καὶ χ. Plu. Frat. 2.487b.

data.quote: εἴρεσθαι δὲ θεῶν ὅστις σε χαλέπτει

children.definition: wound, τινὰ ἰῷ Dosiad. l.c.

children.label: II
children.definition: provoke, enrage, Κύπριδα AP 5.262 ( Agath.):— Med., to be angry, χαλεψαμένης Ἀφροδίτης D.P. 484, cf. A.R. 1.1341; τισι Nic. Th. 309; χαλέπτεσθαί τινί τινος with one for a thing, App. BC 3.43; χαλεψάμενός τινί τινος ib. 3.7; τινι alone, 2.29, al.; χαλέπτεο πένθεϊ θυμόν QS. 3.780:— Pass., χαλεφθείς τινι enraged at one, v.l. in Thgn. 155; μὴ χαλεφθῇς ἐμοί S. Ichn. 328 (lyr.); σύγγνωθί μοι καὶ μὴ χαλεφθῇς Com.Adesp. 281.

children.label: III
children.definition: Act., to be angry, vexed, τινι at a person or thing, Bion Fr. 11.2.:—Poet. and late Prose.
Hsch. χαλίδιον, τό, tablet, Id.
cupbearer, IG 5(1).1468, al. (Messene, χαλειδ- lapides).

definition: χαλικῖτις, ιδος, ἡ, dub. in Ostr.Strassb. 619.2 (ii A. D.).

children.definition: lime-burner, Edict.Diocl. 7.4.

definition: χαλίκραιος, η, ον, = sq., Nic. Al. 29: irreg. Comp. χαλικρότερος, as if from *χαλικρός, ib. 59, 613.

children.definition: unmixed, μέθυ Archil. 78, A.R. 1.473; σπονδαί A. ap. Eust. 1471.2 (v. Nauck ad A. Fr. 448); νᾶμα AP 5.293.6 ( Agath.).
in small masses, Thphr. Lap. 65.

definition: χαλίκωμα, ατος, τό, ( χάλιξ) in pl.,

children.definition: rubble and mortar, concrete, Lat. caementa, Gloss.
ἐπτοῆσθαι), Epich. 200 ( χαλικ- cod. Philem.Gloss.).

a shameless woman, Hsch.; = πόρνη, Suid. ( χαλίμα codd.); of the βάκχαι ( χαλωμένας εἰς συνουσίαν), EM 805.9; also expld. as ἡ ὑπὸ μέθης χαλωμένη, Eust. 1471.3; χαλιμίας and χαλίδας (of the βάκχαι) are vv.ll. in A. Fr. 448 (ap. Sch. A.R. 1.473).
guide with or as with bit and bridle, γλῶσσαν, σῶμα, Ep.Jac. 1.26, 3.2, cf. Luc. Salt. 70, Tyr. 4; ἄνθρωπον Vett.Val. 248.25, cf. Chor. 32.139p.376 F.-R., Lib. Decl. 3 Intr. 1.
guiding as by bit and bridle, τῶν τῆς νεότητος παθῶν Simp. in Epict. p.119D.
guiding as with bit and bridle, Νέμεσις Vett.Val. 131.6, al.
Dim. of χαλινός, Arr. Epict. 4.1.80, PLond. 5.1657.8 (iv/v A. D.); = frenum, Gloss.; also gloss on παρήϊον, Sch.D Il. 4.142.
bridling, epith. of Athena, who bridled Pegasus for Bellerophon, Paus. 2.4.1, 5.
the art of making bridles, Arist. EN 1094a11 (v.l. -ποιητική, as in Asp. in EN 4.26).
bridle-maker, Them. Or. 26.329a, Gloss.

definition: χαλινός ( Aeol. χάλιννος prob. in Et.Gud. 561.5), ὁ, heterocl. pl. χαλινά A.R. 4.1607, Opp. H. 1.191, Plu. QConv. 2.613c, Sor. 1.100, etc.:—

children.definition: bit, once in Hom., ἐν δὲ χαλινοὺς γαμφηλῇς ἔβαλον Il. 19.393; χαλινὸν ἐμβαλεῖν γνάθοις E. Alc. 492; χ. ἐξαιρεῖται X. Eq. 3.2; of the horse, χ. οὐκ ἐπίσταται φέρειν (metaph. of Cassandra) A. Ag. 1066; χ. δέχεσθαι, λαμβάνειν, X. Eq. 3.2, 6.10; λαβεῖν, ἔχειν, Arist. Rh. 1393b16, 21; τὸν χ. ἐνδακεῖν champ the bit, Pl. Phdr. 254d; of the rider, δοτέον τὸν χ. one must give a horse the rein, X. Eq. 10.12; ὀπίσω σπάσαι, ξυνέχειν ἀνάγκῃ, Pl. Phdr. 254e, Luc. DDeor. 24[25].1; [ χ.] εἰς ἄκρον τὸ στόμα καθιέμενος X. Eq. 6.9.—Expld. of the bit, opp. reins ( ἡνίαι), by Poll. 1.148; so ἡνίας τε . . καὶ χ. Pl. R. 601c; χ. τινα χαλκεῖ ἐκδιδόντα σκευάσαι Id. Prm. 127a; κατὰ [τὸν κυνόδοντα] ἐμβάλλεται ὁ χ. Arist. HA 576b18, cf. A. Th. 123 (lyr.), S. OC 1067 (lyr.); but distd. fr. στόμιον by Hdt. 1.215, cf. A. Th. 207 (lyr.), X. Eq. 6.9, 10.9, etc.; and may be used generally for bit and bridle, Hdt. 3.118, 4.64, IG 1(2).374.176, PCair.Zen. 659.11 (iii B. C.).

data.quote: χ.] εἰς ἄκρον τὸ στόμα καθιέμενος

children.definition: anything which curbs, restrains, or compels, Ἀργοῦς χ., of an anchor, Pi. P. 4.25; χ. λινόδετοι, = χαλινωτήρια, E. IT 1043; παρθενίας χ. λύειν, of the virgin zone, Pi. I. 8(7).48; χαλινοῖς ἐν πετρίνοισιν, of Prometheus’ bonds, A. Pr. 562 (anap.); Διὸς χ., of the will of Zeus, ib. 672; χαλινῶν ἀναύδῳ μένει, of forcible constraint, Id. Ag. 238 (lyr.); πολλῶν χαλινῶν ἔργον οἰάκων θʼ ἅμα, i.e. it requires much skill and force to guide, S. Fr. 869; τῷ δήμῳ χ. ἐμβαλεῖν ὕβρεως a bridle to curb their violence, Plu. Comp.Per.Fab. 1, cf. Luc. Herm. 82; τῆς γλώττης τὰ χ. Plu. QConv. 2.613c; ἐπέστω τῷ στόματι χ. Lib. Ep. 315.4; χ. οὐδεὶς ὀμμάτων Philostr. VA 6.11.

children.label: II
children.definition: strap, thong, E. Cyc. 461 (dual).

children.label: III
children.definition: tackle of a ship, IG 2(2).1610.11,14.

children.label: IV
children.definition: corner of the horseʼs mouth, where the bit rests, Poll. 2.90 (pl.); of the human mouth, Nic. Al. 117, 223, PUniv.Giss. 44.7, (ii/i B. C.), Heliod. ap. Orib. 48.31.4, Sor. 1.100, PSI 9.1016.25 (ii B. C.), Aret. SA 1.9, Cael.Aur. TP 1.4, Aët. 8.27; but, = ἡ σύνδεσις τῶν γνάθων, Ruf. Onom. 53, cf. Aët. 8.40.
fangs of serpents, from their shape and position in the mouth, Nic. Th. 234.
bridle-maker, Lat. lorarius, Gloss.; abbreviated χαλινου in Sammelb. 5124.684 (ii A. D.) acc. to Schow.
champing the bit, στόματα Call. Lav.Pall. 12.
bridle or bit a horse, X. Cyr. 3.3.27, An. 3.4.35, HG 7.2.21:— Pass., Id. Eq. 5.1, Plb. 3.65.6, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: curb, bridle, check, τὴν ναῦν Philostr. VA 3.23; [ φόβον, ἐπιθυμίαν] Epicur. Fr. 485; τὴν ὀργήν, τὸν θυμόν, Ps.-Phoc. 57, Them. Or. 34p.454Dind.; τὸ φιλόφωνον καὶ λάλον Plu. Sollert. 2.967b; τὴν ἀλογίαν Hierocl. in CA 8p.431M.; τὴν ἑαυτῶν ἀπληστίαν Lib. Or. 47.35:— Pass., to be bridled, curbed, τῇ φρουρᾷ καὶ τοῖς ὁμήροις Plu. Arat. 38; ὑπὸ τοῦ λόγου Philostr. VA 4.30: abs., to be tongue-tied, Hp. Mul. 1.2.
bridling, X. Eq. 3.11 (pl.), v.l. in Poll. 1.184.
mooring-cables, E. Hec. 539, Opp. H. 1.359, Nonn. D. 3.20.
small stone, pebble, in pl., Arist. Fr. 213; ἐστρωμένη χάλιξιν ὁδός Luc. Trag. 226.

gravel, rubble, used in building, Th. 1.93, PCair.Zen. 760 (iii B. C.), PPetr. 3p.290 (iii B. C.), Plu. Cim. 13; τῇ χ. καταμείξαντες τὴν ἀμμοκονίαν, so as to make concrete, Str. 5.4.6: pl., Ar. Av. 839; χ. σιδηραῖ dub. sens. in IG 1(2).314.44.
neat wine, Hippon. 73, Docum. ant. dell’ Africa Italiana ii Cirenaica 101 (i A. D.), Hsch., Suid., Eust. 1471.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hsch.

children.label: III
children.definition: Them. Or. 23.297a.

definition: χαλιστόν σκαιόν, ἢ ἀγαθὸν καὶ δίκαιον, Hsch.

children.definition: to be light-minded, χαλιφρονέοντα σαοφρονίης ἐπέβησαν, Od. 23.13.
levity, thoughtlessness, 16.310 (in pl.).
light-minded, thoughtless, joined with νήπιος, 4.371, 19.530; of Dionysus (cf. χάλις), AP 9.524.23.

children.label: II
children.definition: of yielding temper, pliable, χ. νεύματα κούρης Musae. 117.
Posidon. 52J., Str. 14.6.5, Dsc. 5.79,98, v.l. in Ruf. ap. Orib. 7.26.38.
resemble χάλκανθον in colour, Ruf. Fr. 79.

children.label: II
children.definition: to be vitriolic, Antyll. ap. Orib. 10.3.6.
solution of blue vitriol ( copper sulphate), used for ink and for shoemakerʼs blacking, Dsc. 3.80, Orph. A. 960, Plin. HN 34.123.

definition: χάλκανθος, ὁ and ἡ, = foreg. 1, acc. to Gal. 12.721, cf. Ruf. ap. Orib. 7.26.38 (v.l.).

children.definition: copper-man, alchemical term in Zos.Alch. p.110B.
vitriolic, of water, Antyll. ap. Orib. 10.3.1, Gal. 13.958.
with brazen chariot, epith. of Ares, Pi. P. 4.87.
with brazen shield, of warriors, Pi. O. 9.54, B. 10.62, Ibyc. 3.31 Diehl, E. HF 795 (lyr.); epith. of Ares, Pi. I. 7(6).25, E. IA 764 (lyr.); of Heracles, S. Ph. 727.

children.label: II
children.definition: οἱ χ., a corps in the Maced. army, Plb. 2.66.5, al., Plu. Sull. 16.

children.label: III
children.definition: one who ran the armed foot-race ( ὁπλιτοδρόμος), Pi. P. 9.1.
with brazen lance, χαλκεγχέων Τρώων E. Tr. 143 (lyr.) ( χαλκέγχεων in cod. Hsch. is wrongly accented, cf. δολιχεγχής).
smithʼs work, Hp. Art. 53; opp. τεκτονική (joinerʼs work), Pl. Prt. 324e, cf. Smp. 197b.

children.label: II
children.definition: smithy, forge, Hero Bel. 98.3.

definition: χαλκεῖον, Ion. χαλκ-ήϊον, τό, = foreg. II, Hdt. 1.68, Hp. Art. 47, 77, And. 1.40, Pl. Euthd. 300b.

children.definition: cauldron, pot, Hdt. 4.81, 152 (v.l. χαλκίον), Hp. Morb. 4.39, Pl. Prt. 329a codd.: esp. copper in baths, Thphr. Char. 9.8; χ. ἐρυθρόν vessel of pure copper, Hp. Ulc. 12; χ. μολυβοῦν POxy. 1648.62 (ii A. D.).
concave metal reflector in a lamp, X. Smp. 7.4.
bronze structure, Paus. 2.22.2.

children.label: III
children.definition: τὰ χαλκεῖα (sc. ἱερά), at Athens, a festival at the end of the month Pyanopsion, Phanod. 22, Hyp. Fr. 90, cf. Poll. 7.105; title of play by Menander.

definition: χάλκειος, η, ον, Ep. for χάλκεος,

children.definition: of copper or bronze, brazen, ἔγχεϊ χαλκείῳ Il. 3.380; αἰχμὴ χ. 4.461; κληΐς Od. 21.7; αὐγὴ χ. gleam of brass, Il. 13.341; χάλκειον γένος, of the Age of brass, Hes. Op. 144; εἰκὼ χαλκείην Maiist. 15: once in Trag., χάλκειον κάρα, S. Fr. 537 (nisi leg. χάλκεον); in late Prose, χάλκειος σφαῖρα S.E. M. 7.376.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., χάλκειος, ἡ, yellow fish thistle, Carlina corymbosa, Thphr. HP 6.4.3, Plin. HN 21.94.
φάρμακον prob. l. in Zos. Alch. p.216B.
χαλκήλατος, πέλεκυς Pi. O. 7.36; θάλαμοι AP 5.216 ( Paul.Sil.); σάλπιγξ Epigr.Gr. 350 ( Nicaea); εἰκών ib. 944 ( Oenoanda).
νᾶες E. IA 1319 (lyr.).
with brazen beak, D.S. 14.59, Plu. Cim. 13, Trag.Adesp. 142, Lyr. in PTeb. 2 ( a) ii 9; χαλκέμβολοι (abs.), as the name of a special kind of ship, Plu. Ant. 35.
brass-clad, Sch. E. Ph. 1130.
of brazen bowels, applied by Suid. to the Grammarian Didymus.
brass-armed, πόλεμος Pi. N. 1.16; στρατιά ib. 11.35.
torsion-engine with metallic strands, Ph. Bel. 56.22.
brass-riveted, δῶμα Simon. 37.7.
Polem. Cyn. 41.

definition: χαλκεοθώραξ, Ion. χαλκεο-θώρηξ, ηκος, ὁ, ἡ,

children.definition: with brazen breastplate, Il. 4.448, 8.62; cf. χαλκοθώραξ.
with heart of brass, Theoc. 13.5.
bronze-tipped, ἰός B. 5.74.
with clang of bronze, μάχα B. 17.59.
skilled in arms, χαλκεομήστορος Ἕκτορος, restored by Burges in E. Tr. 271 (lyr.) from Hsch. ( χαλκεομίστωρ· ἰσχυροφόρος, i. e. χαλκεομήστορος· ἰσχυρόφρονος).
B. Scol.Oxy. 5.8 (and prob. Id. 12.109), Q.S. 1.274; epith. of the planet Mars, Cat.Cod.Astr. 1.173.
with back of brass, κύμβαλα Nonn. D. 10.388.
brass-footed, ἕδρη AP 9.140 ( Claudian.).
with arms or armour of brass, Δαναοί E. Hel. 693 (lyr.).

definition: χάλκεος, έα, Ion. -έη ( Hom. always -είη (v. χάλκειος)), εον (also εος, εον Il. 18.222 ( ὄπα χάλκεον Αἰακίδαο, where Zenod. χαλκέην as disyll.), Hdt. (v. infr.): rarely in Trag., A. Ch. 686, S. Fr. 534.3, 7 (anap.), E. Ion 1; Aeol., Dor. χάλκιος Epich. 79, Alc. 15.3, SIG 945.6 ( Assos, iv B. C.), IGRom. 4.1302.35 ( Cyme, i B. C. /i A. D.), also Boeot., cf. χαλκοῦς; Att. χαλκοῦς, ῆ, οῦν ( IG 1(2).313.55, etc., but χαλκέων δέλτων Pl. Ax. 371a codd.); Ep. also χάλκειος, v. χάλκειος: ( χαλκός):—

children.definition: of copper or bronze, brazen, οὐδός, δόμος, τεῖχος, Il. 8.15, 18.371, Od. 10.4; ἄξων, κύκλα, Il. 13.30, 5.723; χ. Ἀράων θάλαμοι Antim. in PMilan. 17.48; χ. καὶ ἀδαμαντίνοις τείχεσι Aeschin. 3.84; ὀδός Astyd. 9, Ister 30; esp. of arms and armour, ἔγχος, ξίφος, Il. 3.317, 335; σάκος 7.220; θώρηξ, χιτών, 13.398, 440; ἔντεα 18.131, etc.; χαλκέοις ὅπλοις E. Ph. 1359; also λέβητος χαλκέου A. Ch. 686, cf. E. Cyc. 392; χαλκέοισικάδοις, χαλκέοις δρεπάνοις, S. l.c.; in Trag. mostly contr., χαλκοῖς βάθροισι Id. OC 1591; χαλκῆς ὑπαὶ σάλπιγγος Id. El. 711; χαλκῆς ἐκ δέλτου Id. Tr. 683.

children.label: b
children.definition: χ. Ζεύς, χ. Ποσειδέων, a bronze statue of . . , Hdt. 9.81; χ. ταῦρος Pi. P. 1.95; ἡ χαλκῆ Ἀθηνᾶ D. 19.272; ἱστάναι τινὰ χαλκοῦν Id. 13.21; ἄξιος σταθῆναι χαλκοῦς Arist. Rh. 1410a33; στήλη ἐφʼ ᾗ ὁ στρατηγός ἐστιν ὁ χαλκοῦς And. 1.38; cf. χαλκῆ.

data.quote: στήλη ἐφʼ ᾗ ὁ στρατηγός ἐστιν ὁ χαλκοῦς

children.label: c
children.definition: χ. ἀγών a contest for a shield of brass, Pi. N. 10.22.

brazen, i.e. hard, stout, strong, χάλκεος Ἄρης Il. 5.704, etc. (unless wearing brazen armour, cf. χάλκεοι ἄνδρες Orac. ap. Hdt. 2.152); Χαλκοῦς, nickname of Aristomedes, Din. ap. Did. in D. 9.57, Philem. 1.2 D., Plu. Dem. 11; χ. στονόεντʼ ὅμαδον Pi. I. 8(7).27; χ. αὐδά Id. Pae. 2.100; χάλκεον ἦτορ a heart of brass, Il. 2.490; ὄπα χ. 18.222; χ. ὕπνος, i. e. the sleep of death, 11.241; χαλκέοισι νώτοις, of Atlas, E. Ion 1.
χαλκῆ μυῖα, a boyʼs game, a sort of blind-manʼs-buff, Herod. 9a, Poll. 9.123.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., v. χαλκοῦς. [χάλκεοι is disyll. in Hes. Op. 150.]
with bronze breastplate, Ἄρης B. 5.34.
armed in brass, E. Supp. 999 (lyr.).
worker in metal, smith, Epigr.Gr. 269 ( Aedepsus); of Hephaestus, Q.S. 2.440.
with voice of brass, i.e. ringing strong and clear, of Stentor, Il. 5.785; of Cerberus, Hes. Th. 311.
= foreg., αὐλῶν ὀμφά Pi. Pae. 3.94.
anything made of brass, e.g. an axe or sword, A. Ch. 576.
brazen bonds, Id. Pr. 19.

definition: χαλκεύς, έως, ὁ: pl. χαλκεῖς, Att. -ῆς Ar. Av. 490 (anap.), Pl. R. 370d, Ep. -ῆες (v. infr.): acc. χαλκέας Id. Smp. 221e, R. 428d, χαλκεῖς Plu. Apophth. Lac. 2.214a:—

children.definition: coppersmith, opp. τέκτων (joiner, Pl. R. 370d), ἣν [ἀσπίδα] χ. ἤλασεν Il. 12.295, etc.; μίτρη, τὴν χαλκῆες κάμον ἄνδρες 4.187, 216.

worker in metal, of a goldsmith, Od. 3.432; of a worker in iron. 9.391; hence later, blacksmith, smith ( χαλκέας τοὺς τὸν σίδηρον ἐργαζομένους Arist. Po. 1461a29), Hdt. 1.68, Ar. l.c., X. HG 3.4.17; ἀνὴρ χ. Hdt. 4.200; χ. χαλκοῦ καὶ σιδήρου LXX Ge. 4.22.

children.label: II
children.definition: John Dory, Zeus faber, Opp. H. 1.133, prob. in Arist. HA 535b18; distd. fr. χαλκίς, Ath. 7.328d.
Gloss.
AP 7.34 ( Antip. Sid.).
of or for the smithʼs art, φῦσα Hp. Morb. 3.14; ἔργα X. Vect. 4.6; τὸ χ. πῦρ, opp. τὸ μαγειρικόν, Arist. Spir. 485a35.

children.label: II
children.definition: skilled in metal-working, X. Mem. 1.1.7: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) the smithʼs art or trade, Id. Oec. 1.1, Arist. PA 683a24, GA 789b10.
wrought of metal: metaph., στίχος Πιερίδων χ. ἐπʼ ἄκμοσιν AP 7.409 (Antip.).

make of copper or bronze or (generally) of metal, forge, δαίδαλα πολλά Il. 18.400; ξίφος S. Aj. 1034, etc.; τὸν χαλκέα αὐτὸν χ. work him on the anvil, Pl. Euthd. 301d: metaph., ἀψευδεῖ πρὸς ἄκμονι χάλκευε γλῶσσαν Pi. P. 1.86: in Med. sense, πέδας χαλκεύεται αὑτῷ Thgn. 539; χαλκεύεσθε μηνίσκους φορεῖν Ar. Av. 1114 (troch.); ἐχαλκεύσατο κράνη . . ὁλοσίδηρα Plu. Cam. 40:— Pass., to be wrought or forged, ἐξ ἀδάμαντος ἢ σιδάρου κεχάλκευται Pi. Fr. 123.4; ἀφʼ ὁπόσων ταλάντων κεχ. at the cost of . . , Luc. JTr. 11; τῶν κεχαλκευμένων πρὸς ἀπώλειαν ὅπλων D.S. 17.58: metaph., ἐπὶ τοῖς δεδεμένοις χαλκεύεται [ταῦτα] these arms are being forged against . . , Ar. Eq. 469; also of the victims in Phalaris’ bull, Phalar. Ep. 113.

children.label: II
children.definition: to be a smith, Ar. Pl. 163, 513 (anap.), Th. 3.88, Pl. R. 396a; τὸ χαλκεύειν the smithʼs art, X. Mem. 4.2.22.
forge, smithy, βῆ ῥʼ ἴμεν ἐς χαλκεῶνα [where εω must be pronounced as one syll.] Od. 8.273, cf. A.R. 3.41.
bar of wrought iron, Lat. strictura, glossed φυσητήρ, χαλκεών (nisi leg. χαλκέων), Gloss.
bronze statue, Antig. Mir. 15, cf. D.L. 9.39, 10.9.
chalcedony, Apoc. 21.19.
of or for a smith, ὅπλα Od. 3.433; δόμος, i.e. forge, 18.328; in form χαλκεῖος, θῶκος Hes. Op. 493.

forged out of brass, of beaten brass, κώδωνες, σάκος, A. Th. 386, 539; πλάστιγξ Id. Ch. 290; σκάφη Id. Fr. 225; ὅπλα S. Fr. 341; λέβητες ib. 378; ἀσπίς E. Ba. 799, cf. Ar. Ra. 929; cf. χαλκέλατος (q.v.).

furnished or fitted with bronze, of spears and arrows tipped or armed with bronze, ξυστόν, δόρυ, ὀϊστός, ἰοί, Il. 4.469, 5.145, 13.650, Od. 1.262; χαλκήρεον (sic) ἔγχος Pancrat. in POxy. 1085.6; κυνέη, κόρυς, Il. 3.316, 15.535; σάκη 17.268; generally, χ. τεύχεα 15.544; χ. στόλος, of a shipʼs beak, A. Pers. 408; ναῦς χ. Plu. Demetr. 42, Sull. 22.
Hero Bel. 88.5.
costing one χαλκοῦς, PCair.Zen. 19.5 (iii B. C.).
χαλκιαία, ἡ, supplementary tax on sales, Sammelb. 5729 (iii B. C.); abbrev. in Ostr.Bodl. i 96 (ii B. C.); also written χαλκιεία (q. v.).
to be parsimonious, Suid.; cf. Χαλκιδίζω.
inhabitant of Chalcis, Hdt. 5.74, etc.: acc. pl. Χαλκιδέας Ar. Eq. 238.

children.label: II
children.definition: δειλός, Hsch.
Lesb.Gramm. 4.
imitate the Chalcidians in παιδεραστία ( Hsch.) or parsimony ( Eust. 279.18), Com.Adesp. 1192.
of or from Chalcis (in Euboea or Thrace), Alc. 15, Hdt. 7.185, Ar. Eq. 237.

children.label: II
children.definition: χαλκιδική, ἡ, = χαλκίς II, Dorio ap. Ath. 7.328d.
σαύρα χ. = χαλκίς III, σήψ II.2, Dsc. 2.65, Philum. Ven. 34.

children.label: III
children.definition: εἶδος ἀλεκτρυόνος, Hsch.

children.label: IV
children.definition: chalcidicum, = fori deambulatorium, Gloss.
Dim. of χαλκίον 1, Hermipp. 65.
a penny prostitute, Com.Adesp. 1352.
supplementary tax on sales, PLond. 3.1200 (ii B. C.).
shine like brass, χ. τὴν χροιάν Sch. Il. 14.291; of snakes, χρώματι χ. Philum. Ven. 32.1; ring like brass, φωνὴ χαλκίζουσα Poll. 2.117.

children.label: II
children.definition: play the game χαλκισμός, ‘spin a copper’, Alex. 337, Herod. 3.65, Poll. 7.105, 206; cf. χαλκίνδα.
in copper coin, PFrankf. 1.38,91 (iii B. C.).
dwelling in a brazen temple, like χαλκίοικος, Hsch.
παίζειν to play the game χαλκισμός, Hsch.
of bronze, νόμισμα OGI 339.44 ( Sestos, ii B. C.); διάδημα Ostr.Bodl. i 262 (ii B. C.); χαλκίνη (sc. δραχμή) PLond. 2.380 (ii/iii A. D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: concerning or in bronze coin, λόγος PTeb. 119.51 (ii B. C.).

she who dwells in a brazen house (i. e. Athena, whose name is freq. omitted), at Sparta, from the brazen shrine in which her statue stood, E. Hel. 228, 245 (both lyr.), Ar. Lys. 1300 (lyr.), Th. 1.128, 134, Paus. 3.17.2, 10.5.11.
copper vessel, cauldron, kettle, IG 1(2).393, Ar. Ach. 1128, Fr. 107, 330, Eup. 108, 256, X. Oec. 8.19; χ. θερμαντήριον, = θερμαντήρ, IG 2(2).1416, 4.39 ( Aegina), Gal. 13.663.
cymbal, τὸ Δωδωναῖον χ., prov. of a chatterbox, Men. 66, cf. Zen. 6.5.
bowl of the κότταβος, Poll. 6.110.
copper ticket given to the dicasts, bearing the name of the court in which they were to serve, D. 39.10.

piece of copper money, πονηρὰ χαλκία Ar. Ra. 724 (troch.); παραλαβὼν τὼ χαλκίω Eub. 83; cf. Poll. 9.90.—Freq. written χαλκεῖον in codd., but χαλκίον is required by the metre in Com., and corroborated by Inscrr. (v. supr.), and Pap., PCair.Zen. 630.4 (iii B. C.), PMich.Zen. 65.2 (iii B. C.), PSI 6.625.12 (iii B. C.), etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: Dim. of χάλκη, = κάλχη II, IG 42(1).102.242 ( Epid., iv B. C.).
boiler-keeper in a bathing-establishment, Stoic. 1.10, PCair.Zen. 799.8 (iii B. C.).
κύμινδις), Il. 14.291, cf. Arist. HA 615b10, Parth. 13.4:— Cratin. 315 (hex.) parodies Il. l.c., taking χ. in the sense of a brazen pot.
= pica maritima ( i.e. roller, Coracias garrula), Gloss.

children.label: II
children.definition: pilchard or sardine, Clupea sardina, Epich. 48, al., Arist. HA 543a2, Numen. ap. Ath. 7.328d, Opp. H. 1.244; also a freshwater fish, Arist. HA 568a18.

children.label: III
children.definition: lizard, cicigna, ib. 604b23, Plin. HN 32.30, Aët. 13.15; cf. χαλκιδικός II.2.

children.label: IV
children.definition: female slave, Proxen. 8, Eust. 1090.57.

children.label: V
children.definition: Χαλκίς, ίδος, ἡ, Chalcis, name of various cities, Il. 2.537, etc.

definition: χαλκισκάριον, τό, dub. sens. in PLond. 2.191.8 (ii A. D.).

children.definition: game played by spinning a copper coin, which was stopped by the finger before it fell, Poll. 9.118, Eust. 986.41, 1409.18.

definition: χαλκίτης [ῑ], ου, ὁ, = sq. I.2, Gal. 1.452 cod.Marc.(ed. Helmreich), 15.32 (prob. l.).

children.label: II
children.definition: χαλκ-είτης, = χαλκεύς, JHS 32.165 ( Pisidia); written καχείτης ib. 161 (ibid.).
containing copper, λίθος χ. copper-ore, worked in Cyprus, Arist. HA 552b10; and in Euboea, Plu. Def.orac. 2.434a.
rock-alum, Emp. ap. Gal. 15.32 (sed v. foreg.), Dsc. 5.99, POxy. 1088.19 (i A. D.), Sor. 2.41; χ. στυπτηρίη Hp. Ulc. 14; χ. κυανέη (of doubtful nature) ib. 21.
bronze-armed, of men, in gen. pl. -αρᾶν, Pi. I. 4(3).63(81); acc. sg. -άραν ib. 5(4).41.
heavy or loaded with bronze, ἰός Il. 15.465, Od. 21.423; δόρυ 11.532: fem. χαλκο-βάρεια (as if from *χαλκόβαρυς), Il. 11.96, Od. 22.259, 276.
standing on bronze, with brazen base, or with floor of bronze, χαλκοβατὲς δῶ, of the house of Zeus, Od. 8.321, Il. 1.426, 14.173, etc.; of that of King Alcinoüs, Od. 13.4.
S. OC 1046 (lyr.).
with teeth of bronze, ἄγκυρα Pi. P. 4.24.
with point or barbs of bronze, μελίη Il. 22.225.
wrought in bronze, ἀσπίς B. Fr. 6.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., working in brass, τέχνα AP 9.777 ( Phil.).
subduing, i.e. sharpening bronze, a word of masc. termin. with fem. Subst., χαλκοδάμαντʼ ἀκόναν Pi. I. 6(5).73.

definition: χαλκοδεσμωτήρ and χαλκο-δεσμήτωρ, expld. by χαλκόδεσμος ( -δερ- cod.), Hsch.

children.definition: bronze-bound, σάκη A. Th. 160 (lyr.); κοτύλαι Id. Fr. 57.6 (anap.); αὐλαί S. Ant. 945 (lyr.); ἔμβολα E. Ph. 114 (lyr.).
Hdn. Epim. 208.
like copper, copper-coloured, Arist. Col. 793a26; μέλιτται Ael. NA 17.35; ῥάβδοι D.S. 17.90, cf. Dsc. 5.99.

children.label: II
children.definition: cuneiform bone, χ. ὀστέον, ὀστᾶ, PLit.Lond. 167.16 (ii/iii A. D.), Gal. 14.725.
girt with bronze, epith. of Heracles, EM 436.18.
hot bath, Gloss.
boiler-room in baths, POxy. 2146.5 (iii A. D.), Stud.Pal. 20.230 (iv A. D.).

definition: χαλκοθήκη, ἡ, a building on the Acropolis of Athens, IG 22120, 1469.84.

children.label: II
children.definition: case for bronze vessels, provided specially for those of value, Ath. 6.231d.
ringing with or like bronze, Nonn. D. 13.48.

definition: χαλκοκέραυνος, ον, epith. of the sea, perh. f.l. for χαλκ-αμάρυγος, gleaming like copper or bronze, A. Fr. 192.3 (anap.).

children.definition: bronze-greaved, Il. 7.41.
copper-welder, coppersmith, POxy. 85 ii 4 (pl., iv A. D.).
welded, Lat. ferruminatus, Gloss.
bronze-armed, equipped with bronze, Il. 5.699, 6.199, 398, al.; ὅμιλος Pi. Pae. 6.108.
= foreg., IG 2(2).1424 a. 95, 1425.91; νόμισμα Hsch., Choerob. in Theod. 1.132, al.; on the accent v. Hdn.Gr. 1.51, al.

children.label: II
children.definition: copper-headed, i.e. bronze-tipped, of missiles, Tim. Pers. 30.
mixed with copper, Polyaen. 4.10.2.
Nurses of Dionysus, Plu. QConv. 2.672b (dub. l.).
sounding or rattling with bronze, epith. of Demeter, in allusion to instruments used in her worship, Pi. I. 7(6).3; χ. ἵπποι horses that stamp with hoofs of bronze, brazen-hoofed, Ar. Eq. 552 (lyr.).

children.label: II
children.definition: E. Ph. 1577 (lyr.); χαλκόκροτα bronze utensils, POxy. 1657.1 (iii A. D.).

children.label: III
children.definition: χαλκοκρότος, ὁ, = Lat. aerarius, Gloss. ( καλκόκροτος cod.).

definition: χαλκόκτυπος, ον, = foreg.1, καναχά prob. in B. 13.16; κύμβαλα, Diog.Ath. 1.3.

children.definition: brazen-mouthed, σάλπιγξ B. 17.3.
fine brass, brass of Lebanon, or yellow frankincense, Apoc. 1.15, 2.18.
copper ore, copper, Ps.-Democr.Alch. p.54B.
collect or exact copper money, Rev. Épigr. 1.239 ( Naples, ii A. D.), Lyd. Mag. 3.37, Hsch., Gloss.
collector of money, IG 14.759 ( Naples), MAMA 3.514 (Corycus, written χαρκ-), Gloss.
with bronze crest, Hsch. (s. v.l.).
with μίτρη of bronze, Κάστωρ Pi. N. 10.90 (to be restored for χαλκεομ-):—also χαλκό-μιτρος, ον, Lyc. 997.
alloy of copper and lead, Maria ap. Olymp.Alch. 93B.
a fly of bright metallic hue, ingredient of an eye-salve, Aët. 7.100.
coppersmith, PMasp. 143r14 (vi A. D.).
bronze-backed, ἀσπίς, ἰτέα, E. Tr. 1136, 1193.
made of bronze, σάλπιγξ AP 6.46 ( Antip.Sid.).
with cheeks or sides of bronze, epith. of helmets, Il. 12.183, 17.294, 20.397, Od. 24.523; of a javelin, Pi. P. 1.44, N. 7.71; κρέμβαλα Carm.Pop. 3.
with floor of bronze, ἕδρα θεῶν Pi. I. 7(6).44.
bronze-worker, LXX Wi. 15.9.
with sides of bronze, τύπωμα χ., of a cinerary urn, S. El. 54.
multitudinous and bronze-clad, στρατός E. Supp. 1220.
smiting with brazen edge, γένυς, of the battle-axe, S. El. 484 (lyr.; also expld. as = χαλκήλατος).
metalworker, Sammelb. 5726.

with feet of bronze, τρίπους E. Supp. 1197; ὀδός, founded on bronze, S. OC 57 (expld. by Sch. with ref. to copper-mines): in Hom. of horses, to express the solid strength of their hoofs, χαλκόποδʼ ἵππω Il. 8.41; ταῦροι Pherecyd. 112J.; χ. Ἐρινύς, to express her untiring pursuit, S. El. 491 (lyr.); of Empedocles, with bronze slippers, Luc. DMort. 6[20].4.
with prow of bronze, of ships, Poll. 2.102.
with wings of metallic hue, ὄρνις PSI 6.569.9 (iii B. C.); μυῖα Philum. Ven. 25.1.
copper-smelter, IG 2.2867 (fort. χαλκο<κό>πτης) ; [χαλκ]όπτης dub. in PCair.Goodsp. 30 xii 30 (ii A. D.).
with gates of brass or bronze, ἱρόν Hdt. 1.181; χ. θεά, epith. of Athena, E. Tr. 1113 (lyr.); ὕδωρ, of Castalia, because issuing from bronze spouts in the shape of lions’ heads, Pi. Pae. 6.7.

definition: χαλκοπώγων, ωνος, ὁ, transl. of Lat. Ahenobarbus, Plu. Aem. 25, D.Chr. 37.40.

children.definition: dealer in copper or bronze, Critias Fr. 70 D., Poll. 7.196.
with roof of bronze, παρθενεών Nonn. D. 47.543 (s. v. l.).

definition: χαλκορυχεῖον, τό, f.l. for χαλκωρυχεῖον (q. v.), Thphr. Lap. 25.
χαλκός, Cret. καυχός GDI 5011.4 (iii B. C.), ὁ:—

children.definition: copper, χ. ἐρυθρός Il. 9.365; with reference to its polished surface, αἶθοψ, ἦνοψ, νῶροψ, φαεινός, 4.495, 16.408, 2.578, 12.151; Τρῶες . . χαλκῷ μαρμαίροντες 13.801; πεδίον . . λάμπετο χαλκῷ 20.156; τῆλε δὲ χ. λάμφʼ ὥς τε στεροπή 10.153, cf. 11.65, 19.363; σάκος . . χαλκῷ παμφαῖνον 14.11; and of the ornaments of a house, χαλκοῦ τε στεροπήν Od. 4.72; of copper as the first metal that men learnt to smelt and work, τῶν δʼ ἦν χάλκεα μὲν τεύχεα, χάλκεοι δέ τε οἶκοι, χαλκῷ δʼ εἰργάζοντο, μέλας δʼ οὐκ ἔσκε σίδηρος Hes. Op. 151; χ. ἐρυθρός (cf. supr.) Hp. Ulc. 17, Thphr. Lap. 57, Callix. 1; χ. ἐρυθρὸς καὶ λευκός Thphr. Od. 71; χ. Κύπριος Posidon. 52J., Dsc. 1.102, cf. Polyaen. 3.10.14; alloyed with tin to form bronze, the usual meaning of the word in Hom. (v. infr. II) and freq. in later writers: σίδηρος δὲ καὶ χ. πολέμων ὄργανα Pl. Lg. 956a, etc.; χ. κεκραμένος D.Chr. 28.3.

data.quote: τῆλε δὲ χ. λάμφʼ ὥς τε στεροπή
τῶν δʼ ἦν χάλκεα μὲν τεύχεα, χάλκεοι δέ τε οἶκοι, χαλκῷ δʼ εἰργάζοντο, μέλας δʼ οὐκ ἔσκε σίδηρος
σίδηρος δὲ καὶ χ. πολέμων ὄργανα

children.label: II
children.definition: anything made of metal, esp. of arms (hence Pi. calls it πολιός, the proper epith. of iron, P. 3.48); of offensive arms, ὀξέϊ χαλκῷ, νηλέϊ χ., of a spear, a sword, Il. 4.540, 3.292, al.; of a knife, 1.236, al.; of an axe, 13.180, Od. 5.244, al.; of a fish-hook, Il. 16.408; of defensive arms, as the plates laid on a shield, 20.275; χαλκὸν ζώννυσθαι, of a warrior girding on his armour, 23.130; κεκορυθμένος, αἴθοπι χ. 4.495; ἐδύσετο νώροπα χ. 2.578; of both combined, πλάγχθη δʼ ἀπὸ χαλκόφι χαλκός the spear of bronze glanced off the helm of bronze, 11.351.

copper, cauldron, urn, 18.349, Od. 8.426; of a cinerary urn, S. El. 758; collectively of bronze plate, χ. μυρίος, Pi. N. 10.45; θάλαμον . . , ὅθι νητὸς χρυσὸς καὶ χ. ἔκειτο Od. 2.338, cf. 13.19, 21.10, 62, Il. 2.226; used in payment of ransom, 22.50, cf. 340, Od. 5.38.

data.quote: θάλαμον . . , ὅθι νητὸς χρυσὸς καὶ χ. ἔκειτο

children.definition: bronze mirror, A. Fr. 393, Call. Lav.Pall. 21, Ap 6.210 ( Philet.); used as a burning-glass, Thphr. Ign. 73.

copper money, IPE 12.24.15 ( Olbia, iv B. C.), Ev.Matt. 10.9, Ev.Marc. 12.41, cf. ἰσόνομος II; generally, money, opp. κύαμοι, IG 14.423 ii 21 ( Tauromenium), cf. BGU 822.12 (iii A. D.), etc.; χαλκοῦ σπάνις Men. Mon. 156; χαλκὸν ἔχων πῶς οὐδὲν ἔχεις μάθε AP 11.167 (Pollian.).

data.quote: χαλκὸν ἔχων πῶς οὐδὲν ἔχεις μάθε

children.definition: bronze plate or tablet, τὰν προξενίαν γράψαντας εἰς χαλκὸν ἀνθέμεν IG 9(1).682 ( Corcyra, iv B. C.); οὐετρανοὶ οἱ χωρὶς χαλκῶν, who have not received bronze copies of the privileges granted on discharge, BGU 113.5 (ii A. D.), etc.

data.quote: τὰν προξενίαν γράψαντας εἰς χαλκὸν ἀνθέμεν

children.label: III
children.definition: χαλκοῦ ἄνθος, particles thrown off by copper when cooling, Hp. Mul. 1.104, Ph. Bel. 102.34, Dsc. 5.77.

children.label: b
children.definition: χαλκοῦ λεπίς, small pieces that scale off under the hammer, ib. 78. (Perh. cf. Lith. geležìs ‘iron’.)
with sandals of bronze, Porph. ap. Eus. PE 3.11.
with legs of bronze, βοῦς S. Fr. 336.
a green stone with metallic veins, perhaps malachite, Plin. HN 37.74.
Phleg. Fr. 36.3J.
bronze-crowned, τέμενος Epigr. ap. D.S. 11.14.
with mouth of bronze, χ. κώδων Τυρσηνική, i.e. a trumpet, S. Aj. 17.

children.label: II
children.definition: with edge or point of bronze, ἔμβολοι A. Pers. 415, Aristid. Or. 25(43).4; μέτρον POxy. 101.40 (ii A. D.).
with walls of bronze, αὐλά B. 3.32.
made of bronze, κλῇθρα E. IT 99.
scutra, Gloss.
torsion-engine with strands of bronze, Ph. Bel. 67.43, cf. χαλκέντονον.
armed with brazen bow, Pi. N. 3.38.
wrought of bronze, τρίαινα Orph. H. 17.2.
to work or form of bronze, ἔντεα APl. 16.15.
of piercing, sharp bronze, ξίφη Pi. P. 4.147.
caused by piercing with bronze, ὠτειλαί Opp. H. 5.329 (expld. by χαλκο-τρύπητοι Sch.).
forge, smithy, Ph. 1.153, Nicom. Harm. 6.
work in bronze: τιμαὶ -τυπούμεναι, of honorary statues, wrought in bronze, Plu. Praec. 2.820b.
wound by stroke of sword, Anon. ap. Suid. s.v. χαλκοτύπους (pl.).
art of a χαλκοτύπος, Pl. Plt. 288a, Plu. Comm.not. 2.1084c.

forging or working copper, τέχναι Man. 4.570; ἀνὴρ ἐν Κορίνθῳ χ. Plu. Pyth. 2.395c:— Subst., coppersmith, χ. καὶ σιδηρεῖς X. Ages. 1.26. Vect. 4.6; generally, smith, Lycurg. 58, D. 25.38, IGRom. 4.1259 ( Thyatira), etc.; but distd. from χαλκεύς, X. HG 3.4.17.
μανίη, of the priests of Cybele, AP 6.51.

children.label: II
children.definition: χαλκότῠπος, ον, Pass., inflicted with arms of bronze, ὠτειλαί Il. 19.25.
wrought of bronze, εἰκών APl. 16.362.

children.label: II
children.definition: foundry, Dsc. 5.75.
work in bronze, Clara Rhodos 6/7.403 ( Camirus, iii B. C.).
work of bronze, J. AJ 8.3.5, S.E. M. 9.75, BGU 362i 8 (iii A. D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Peripl.M.Rubr. 24, Supp.Epigr. 6.616 ( Pisidia).
working in bronze, Poll. 7.104.

definition: χαλκουργικός, ή, όν: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) the

children.definition: coppersmithʼs art, Arist. Pol. 1256a6.
working copper, χ. μέταλλα copper mines, Dsc. 5.91 (nisi leg. -ουργικά): Subst. -γός, ὁ, miner, Posidon. 47J.; worker in bronze, Luc. JTr. 33, BGU 362x17 (iii A.D.).

definition: χαλκοῦς, ῆ, οῦν, Att. contr. from χάλκεος, q.v.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. χαλκοῦς, ὁ, copper coin used at Athens, 1/8 of an obol, Ar. Ec. 815, 818, D. 42.22, Alex. 15.2, Philem. 64, 74, Cerc. 17.41, Plu. QConv. 2.665b, etc.: in pl., money, PCair.Zen. 519 (iii B. C.), etc.
adorned with brass, δώματα Ar. Ach. 1072.
having the appearance of copper, Dsc. 5.74.

definition: χαλκόφι, Ep. gen. from χαλκός, Il. 11.351.

children.definition: producing copper, rich in copper, Eust. 1409.8.

children.label: II
children.definition: tipped with copper, θύρσος Nonn. D. 14.343.
Subst., ἡ, name of a metallic-sounding stone, Plin. HN 37.154.
fighting in armour of bronze, ξένοι Τρῶες Pi. P. 5.82; χ. πόλεμος Id. I. 6(5).27 (also expld. as (from χάρμα), delighting in arms).
bronze-clad, Ἀχαιοί Il. 1.371, 2.47, etc.; Τρῶες 5.180, al.; Βοιωτοί 15.330; Κρῆτες 13.255; Δαναοὶ πύκα χ. Epigr. ap. Aeschin. 3.185.
copper-coloured, Dsc. 2.182.
cast in bronze, πλευραὶ βοός AP 9.739 ( Jul.).
turn to bronze, πόρτιν AP 9.795 ( Jul.):— Pass., ib. 716 ( Anacr.).

children.label: II
children.definition: χαλκωθείς clad in bronze, Pi. O. 13.86.

definition: χαλκύδριον, τό, Dim. of χαλκός, Zos.Alch. p.216B., Theognost. Can. fol.83 (om. Cramer p.126, ante νεανισκύδριον): pl.,

children.definition: small change, BGU 1821.12 (i B. C.).
like bronze, χρῶμα Thphr. Sign. 51; ὄττιες Aret. SD 2.13.
bronze-beaked, στόλοι Hsch. ( -όδ- cod., extra ordinem).

anything made of bronze or copper, vessel, instrument, Ar. V. 1214, Fr. 436, Lys. 19.27, X. An. 4.1.8, Sophr. 30, Nicostr. 21.4, PCair.Zen. 40.1 (iii B. C.), BGU 993 iii 12 (ii B. C.), Sor. 2.29, etc.; ἀσπίδος τὸ χ. the bronze-work, opp. τὸ ξύλον, Arist. Mete. 371a26, cf. Aen. Tact. 37.7; cauldron, Plu. Demetr. 24.

copper plate or tablet, for engraving records on, Plb. 3.26.1, 3.33.18, IG 9(1).685, al. ( Corcyra, ii B. C.), 14.612 ( Rhegium, i B. C.), 952.22 ( Agrigentum, iii B. C.), 953.24 ( Melita, iii B. C.); written χάλχωμα, JHS 32.160 ( Pisidia).

children.label: b
children.definition: metal plate, Plb. 6.23.14.
beak of a ship, D.S. 20.9, Plu. Ant. 67, etc.
Dim. of χάλκωμα, Inscr.Délos 1417 A i 104 (ii B. C.), Hsch. s.v. πλάτων.
maker of bronze plates, PRyl. 397.3 (iii A. D.).

definition: χαλκών, ῶνος, ὁ, cited as a collective noun by Hdn.Gr. 1.29.

children.definition: bought with money, Hsch., cf. ἀργυρώνητος.
with brazen hoofs, ταῦροι Sch. A.R. 3.233.
copper-mine, Thphr. Lap. 25, Str. 17.2.2, Plu. QConv. 2.659c, better written χαλκωρῠχ-ρύχιον, as in PPetr. 3p.320 (iii B. C.), Str. l.c. (v. l.), Plu. l.c. (codd.).
dig or mine copper, Lyc. 484.
digging copper, copper miner, Tz.ad Lyc. 484.
measure used in Egypt, τὸν χαλμαίαν τοῦ ἐλαίου PSI 5.531 (iii B. C.).

definition: Χαλυβδικός or Χᾰλῠβικός (later, acc. to St. Byz.), ή, όν,

children.definition: Chalybian, σίδηρος ὁ Χαλυβικός Arist. Mir. 833b22: Χαλύβινος is v.l. in Sch. S. Tr. 1259 cod.Laur.: ἡ X. the land of the Chalybes, Hsch.
of steel, Cratin. 247, Lyc. 1109; ἄτερ Χαλυβδικοῦ without Chalybian, i.e. without steel, E. Heracl. 161; Χ. στόμωμα, v. στόμωμα.

definition: χαλυβηΐς, ίδος, poet. fem. of χαλυβδικός, Max. 302.

children.definition: the Chalybes in Pontus, who were famous for the preparation of steel, οἱ σιδηροτέκτονες Χάλυβες A. Pr. 715, cf. Hdt. 1.28, X. An. 5.5.1, Call. in PSI 9.1092.48 (on another nation of the same name v. Str. 12.3.20).

children.label: II
children.definition: χάλυψ, hardened iron, steel, A. Pr. 133 (lyr.), S. Tr. 1260 (anap.), Antip.Sid. in POxy. 662.52; of a penknife, AP 6.65 ( Paul.Sil.); of an axe, APl. 16.127: as Adj., Nonn. D. 36.182:—also Χάλυβος, ον, Χάλυβος Σκυθῶν ἄποικος, i.e. steel, A. Th. 728 (lyr.); Χαλύβῳ πελέκει E. Fr. 472.6 (anap.): pl., = Χάλυβες, E. ap. Sch.Il. Oxy. 1087 i 28; τὸν ἐν Χαλύβοις σίδαρον Id. Alc. 980 (lyr.).

definition: χαμάδις [ᾰδ] ( χᾰμάδι read in Od. 19.599 by Eust. 1879.53, cf. χαμάνδις), Adv., Ep. for χαμᾶζε,

children.definition: to the ground, on the ground, τὰ μέν τʼ ἄνεμος χ. χέει Il. 6.147; χ. πέσε 7.16; χ. βάλε ib. 190, etc.; once in Trag., A. Th. 358 (lyr.).

data.quote: τὰ μέν τʼ ἄνεμος χ. χέει

children.definition: earth-creeper, i.e. snail, Hsch.

to the ground, on the ground, freq. in Hom., ἐξ ὀχέων σὺν τεύχεσιν ἆλτο χ. Il. 3.29, al.; ἀπὸ πύργου βαῖνε χ. stepped to the ground, 21.529; [ κεραυνὸν] ἧκε χ. 8.134, cf. 14.497, 20.461; χ. κάππεσεν 15.537; τόξον . . θῆκε χ. Od. 21.136, cf. 22.340: rare in Trag. and Com., E. Ba. 633 (troch.), Ar. Ach. 341, 344 (both troch.); μὴ πέσῃ χ. Id. V. 1012 (lyr.); χ. προβαίνουσα Babr. 115.13; freq. in later Prose, χ. θυρεοῖς κεκλιμένοις Plu. Sull. 28; ἔχειν χ. δύʼ ὀβολώ Luc. Lex. 2. (On the exceptional accent cf. Ael.Dion. Fr. 322, Hdn.Gr. 2.951.)

data.quote: ἐξ ὀχέων σὺν τεύχεσιν ἆλτο χ.

children.definition: from the ground, Hdt. 2.125, 4.172, Eup. 146b, Ar. V. 249, the Attic form, acc. to A.D. Adv. 187.7 (who also gives χαμαῖθεν which is found in Plu. Aet.Gr. 2.296e; χαμάθεν [ᾰ] is v.l. in Hdt. 2.125).

children.label: II
children.definition: χαμόθεν is found in Cratin. 296, X. HG 7.2.7, Stesich. ap. Arist. Rh. 1395a2, Plu. Alex. 35, Luc. Ind. 9, and was the colloquial form acc. to A.D. Adv. 188.33.

on the ground, χ. ἧσθαι Od. 7.160; τὸν αὖ χ. ἐξενάριξε Il. 11.145; χ. ἐρχομένων ἀνθρώπων 5.442, cf. Sapph. 94, etc.; χ. τιθεὶς πόδα A. Ag. 906; αἷμα μητρῷον χ. Id. Eu. 261 (lyr.), cf. Ar. Ach. 869, Eq. 155, Nu. 231, al.; θέντες χ. Hdt. 4.67; χ. καθίζοντες Pl. Criti. 120b; χ. κείμενος IG 2(2).1672.305; of birds, ποιεῖν νεοττιὰν χ., opp. ἐπὶ δένδρου, Arist. HA 618a10.
ἐσλὸν χ. σιγᾷ καλύψαι to bury in silence underground, Pi. N. 9.7; χ. ἐρχόμενοι cleaving to earth, Luc. Herm. 5, Icar. 6; ὁ χ. βίος Metrod. Fr. 38.

children.label: II
children.definition: to earth, ἐν κονίῃσι χ. πέσεν Il. 4.482; χ. βάλον ἐν κονίῃσι 5.588, cf. Od. 22.188, Il. 4.526; ἐκ δίφροιο χαμαὶ θόρε 8.320; μὴ χ. πεσεῖν to the ground, E. Med. 1170; οὐ χ. πεσεῖται ὅ τι ἂν εἴπῃς Pl. Euthphr. 14d; ἔπτυσε χ. Ev.Jo. 9.6; also ἐκβαλεῖν εἰς τὸ χ. AP 11.89 ( Lucill.). (Cf. Lat. humus, humi, Lith. žẽmė ‘earth’.)

data.quote: οὐ χ. πεσεῖται ὅ τι ἂν εἴπῃς

children.definition: elder, Sambucus Ebulus, Ps.- Dsc. 4.173, Plin. HN 24.51.
blackberry, Rubus ulmifolius, Thphr. HP 3.18.4.
earth-born, epith. of men, h.Ven. 108, h.Cer. 352, Hes. Th. 879, Pi. P. 4.98; of ants, Nonn. D. 13.209.
periwinkle, Vinca herbacea, Thphr. HP 3.18.13, Plin. HN 21.172.
elementary schoolmaster, Edict.Diocl. 7.66, Paul.Al. O. 2, Sch. Ar. Ec. 804, Hierocl. Facet. 61.

definition: χαμαιδικαστής, οῦ, ὁ, = Lat. judex pedaneus, Lyd. Mag. 3.8: hence χᾰμαι-δῐκαστέω, fill this office, PLips. 64.30 (iv A. D.).

children.definition: Androm. ap. Gal. 14.40.
flavoured with germander, Dsc. 5.41.
germander, Teucrium Chamaedrys, Thphr. HP 9.9.5, Dsc. 3.98, Plin. HN 24.130; gen. sg. written χαμέτρυος BKT 3p.32 (v/vi A. D.).
χᾰμαί-ρωψ (q. v.).
PGen. 68.16 (iv A. D.).
lying, sleeping on the ground, Σελλοί Il. 16.235; λέοντες Emp. 127; ἔρως Max.Tyr. 24.8:—fem. χᾰμαι-ευνάς, άδος, σύες Od. 10.243, 14.15; Com., of parasites, Eub. 139 (lyr.).
found on the ground, Anon. ap. Suid.

definition: χαμαίζηλος, ον ( η, ον Hp. Art. 13):—

children.definition: seeking the ground, low-growing, dwarf, χ. φυτά, opp. δένδρα, Arist. HA 559a13; κόνυζα Nic. Th. 70; οἱ χ. φοίνικες dwarf-palms (cf. χαμαιριφής II) Dsc. 1.109; καρποὶ καὶ λάχανα Jul. Or. 5.175d: generally, τὰ ἐγγὺς ἡμῶν καὶ χ. Them. Or. 26.327d.

children.label: b
children.definition: sunk down, ἡ ἐπωμὶς φαίνεται χ. Hp. l.c.; τῇ ἡλικίᾳ χαμαίζηλος Luc. pro Im. 13.
χαμαίζηλος (sc. δίφρος, which is added by Plu. Symp. 2.150a), ὁ, low seat, stool, Hp. Fract. 37, Pl. Phd. 89b.

children.label: b
children.definition: χ. κρατῆρες flat bowls, Polem.Hist. 83.
Ζεὺς χ., = χθόνιος, Orph. A. 931; Ποσειδῶν χ. IG 2(2).1367.

children.label: II
children.definition: of low estate, humble, ψυχή Ph. 1.91, cf. 240, al., Luc. Somn. 13; τὰ χ. Them. Or. 15.184d; χ. δικαστής, = judex pedaneus, Lyd. Mag. 2.15. Adv. -λως Ph. 1.103.

children.label: III
children.definition: χαμαίζηλον, τό, = γναφάλιον, Plin. HN 27.88.

definition: χαμαιζυμήτης ἄρτος, ὁ, sine expl., Suid. (leg. -ίτης).

children.definition: with creeping stalk, Thphr. HP 6.5.2.
Asclep.Myrl. ap. Ath. 2.50e.
dwarf cherry, Prunus prostrata, Plin. HN 15.104.
May lily, Convallaria majalis, interpol. in Dsc. Eup. 1.154 Sprengel (post 145 W.).
ground-ivy, Glechoma hederacea, Dsc. 4.125, Plin. HN 24.135.
lying on the ground, lying flat, κάλαμοι Megasth. 13; creeping, καυλοί Dsc. 4.71.
lie on the ground, Luc. Syr.D. 55 (v.l. χαμοκοιτέων).
a lying or sleeping on the ground, v.l. in Philostr. Ep. 29 (pl.).
bed on the ground, Suid. s.v. στιβάδες.
lavender cotton, Santolina Chamaecyparissus, Poet. de herb. 106, Plin. HN 24.136.
Nic. Th. 656.
Dsc. 3.112; also = χαμαίκισσος, ib. 4.125.
on the ground, κοίτα AP 7.413 (Antip.).
chameleon, Chamaeleo vulgaris, Arist. HA 503a15, Plin. HN 8.120, Lib. Or. 1.249; used as an image of changefulness, Arist. EN 1100b6, Plu. Alc. 23.

children.label: II
children.definition: from their leaves changing colour, Thphr. HP 6.4.3, 9.12.1, 9.14.1; χ. λευκός pine-thistle, Atractylis gummifera, Dsc. 3.8; χ. μέλας, Cardopatium corymbosum, ib. 9, Plin. HN 22.47.

definition: χαμαιλίβανος [ῐ], ὁ, a kind of λίβανος, Aët. 1.129.

children.definition: Dsc. 4.60; χᾰμαί-λῠκον, τό, PMag.Par. 1.2307.
preparation of camomile, interpol. in Orib. 5.33.7.
camomile-oil, Alex.Trall. 1.10.
made of χαμαίμηλον, Gal. 12.507, interpol. in Dsc. Eup. 1.120.
earth-apple, camomile, Orph. A. 921.
Plin. HN 15.27, 23.165, prob. to be read for sq.

definition: χαμαιμύρτη, ἡ, = foreg., dub. l. in Dsc. 4.144.

children.definition: being χαμαιπετής, Iamb. Protr. 21. ισ.
fall to the ground, γνώμα χαμαιπετοῖσα thought that falls to the ground, Pi. N. 4.41 (sed leg. χαμαὶ πετοῖσα).

falling to the ground, χ. πίπτει πρὸς οὖδας E. Ba. 1111 (s. v. l.); φόνος χ. blood that has fallen on the earth, Id. Or. 1491 (lyr.); δόμοι . . χαμαιπετεῖς ἔκεισθʼ ἀεί ye were lying prostrate, A. Ch. 964 (lyr.); grovelling, μηδὲ . . χαμαιπετὲς βόαμα προσχάνῃς ἐμοί Id. Ag. 920; χ. [βέλος], of a spent missile, Aen.Tact. 32.9; χ. ἐλαῖαι windfall olives, Luc. Lex. 13.
lying or sleeping on the ground, χ. ἀεὶ ὢν καὶ ἄστρωτος Pl. Smp. 203d.
on the ground, χ. στιβάς, εὐνή, E. Tr. 507, Cyc. 386; δεῖπνον Posidon. 5J.
creeping, dwarf, Plb. 13.10.8.
flying low, χ. στρουθοί Luc. Dips. 2.
Adv. -τῶς along the ground, like a gooseʼs flight, Id. Icar. 10.

children.label: II
children.definition: falling to the ground, i.e. coming to naught, λόγοι, ἔπος, Pi. O. 9.12, P. 6.37.
grovelling, low, of style, κομιδῇ πεζὸν καὶ χ. Luc. Hist.Conscr. 16, cf. Somn. 13.
fishbone thistle, Chamaepeuce mutica, Dsc. 4.126, Plin. HN 24.136.
ground-pine, Ajuga Chamaepitys, Nic. Al. 56, Apollod. ap. Ath. 15.681d, Dsc. 3.158, Plin. HN 24.29.
mountain germander, Teucrium montanum, Dsc. l.c., Plin. l.c.
herb-ivy, Ajuga Iva, Dsc. and Plin. ll.cc.
Dsc. 4.144:—hence χᾰμαιπῐτύϊνος οἶνος wine flavoured with one of these plants, Dsc. 5.70.
dwarf plane, Plin. HN 12.13.
going on foot, Poll. 2.195, 3.40.
Paul.Aeg. 7.4:—spelt χᾰμαι-ρέφᾰνος Orib. Fr. 52, Hippiatr. 130.184.
creeping on the ground, grovelling, Gal. 12.308. Adv. -πῶς Hsch.
thrown to the ground, mined, νηόν Inscr. in Ferri Contributi di Cirene alla storia della religione greca (Rome, 1923) 5 (ii A. D.), cf. Eust. 1279.45.

children.label: b
children.definition: = foreg. [χαμαιρεπής] I, Sch.Gen. Il. 5.442; παιδία EM 781.36.
= collecticius, Gloss.

children.label: II
children.definition: φοῖνιξ χ. dwarf-palm, Chamaerops humilis, Thphr. HP 2.6.11 (nisi leg. χαμαιρεπής as in Plin. HN 13.39).
Dsc. 3.98 (v.l. χαμαίδρωψ), Paul.Aeg. 7.3; acc. sg. chamaeropem Plin. HN 24.130 (elsewh. only nom.).

children.label: II
children.definition: dwarf-palm, v.l. in Plin. HN 13.39.
a bed on the ground, Sch. S. Ph. 33.
strewed or stretched on the ground, νέκυς alcmaeonis 2p.76K.; χαμαίστρωτα beds on the floor, Ph. 2.482.
thyme spurge, Euphorbia Chamaesyce, Dsc. 4.169, Plin. HN 24.134: Adj. χᾰμαι-σύκινος, η, ον, Gloss.
branching from the ground upwards, πίσος Thphr. CP 4.14.4.
brothel, Phld. Rh. 2.281S., Ph. 2.228, Luc. DMort. 20[10].11, Nigr. 22, Jul. Or. 6.186d.
to be a prostitute, D.Chr. 33.60.
harlot, strumpet, Timocl. 22.2, Men. 879, Sam. 133, Theopomp.Hist. 217 codd. Ath. ( χαμαιτύπους codd. Plb.), Phld. Rh. 1.236S., Ph. 2.48, Plu. Lib.educ. 2.5b.
vulgar, τὸ χ. vulgarity of style, D.H. Th. 27.
whoredom, Alciphr. 3.64, Man. 4.353.
Thom.Mag. p.400R.
striking its prey near or on the ground, name of a certain hawk, opp. μετεωροθήρας, Arist. HA 620a31.

children.label: II
children.definition: χαμαιτύπος πόρνη, = Lat. scortum, Gloss.; but αἱ χαμαιτύποι is prob. f. l. for αἱ χαμαιτύπαι (corr. Wendland) in Ph. 1.345, cf. χαμαιτύπη.
Theognost. Can. 163.
Hsch.
spurge-olive, Daphne oleoïdes, Nic. Al. 48, Dsc. 4.171, Plin. HN 15.24, 24.133.
flavoured with χαμελαία, Dsc. 5.69.
crawling on the ground, μέροπες App.Anth. 3.146 (Theon); ζῷον Olymp.Alch. p.102 B., Hsch.
Hsch., EM 806.25.
pallet-bed, IG 1(2).330.5, Nicaenet. 6.3, Eleg.Alex.Adesp. 2.17.
on the ground, εὐναί Lyc. 848.
having their lair on the ground, βοῦς, λέαινα, φώκη, Nonn. D. 4.348, 6.299, 43.339.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., lair, Nic. Th. 23.
lie on the ground, Ph. 1.640, Philostr. VA 6.10, Gal. Protr. 13.
a bed on the ground, A. Ag. 1540 (anap.), S. Fr. 175, E. Rh. 852, Theoc. 13.33, A.R. 4.883, Herod. 3.16; χ. φυλλόστρωτος E. Rh. 9 (anap.).
bedstead, Ar. Av. 816.
one who sleeps on the ground, Hsch.
a lying on the ground, Ph. 1.323 (pl.), Gal. 17(2).642, Philostr. VA 3.15, Gym. 43.

children.label: II
children.definition: sleeping-mats, Poll. 6.11.

definition: χαμεύνιον, τό, Dim. of χαμεύνη, Pl. Smp. 220d, Luc. Asin. 51, Poll. 6.9.

children.definition: sleeping on the ground, Hsch.
on the ground, creeping, λειχήν Nic. Th. 944; πίτυς χ., = χαμαίπιτυς, ib. 841: Comp. -ότερος Id. Fr. 70.2.
low, = χθαμαλός, Str. 10.2.12; of a horseʼs hoofs, flat, X. Eq. 1.3.
diminutive, trifling, στιγμῆς εἴ τι -ότερον AP 7.472.4 ( Leon.); χαμηλὰ πνέων one of a low spirit, Pi. P. 11.30.

definition: χαμῖτις ἄμπελος, ἡ, a vine trained

children.definition: low on the ground, Gp. 3.1.5, Eust. 1163.19; without ἄμπελος, Suid.
Hsch. (In Mod. Gk. = thin, watery.)

definition: χαμόκοιτος ὁ εἰς τὴν γῆν κοιμώμενος, Hsch.

children.definition: flat tomb, Heuzey-Daumet, Mission Archéologique de Macédoine No. 49.
stludio, Gloss., and χᾰμ-ουλκίς, ίδος, ἡ, = sclodia, ib. (both perh. Dim. of χαμουλκός).
crane or windlass, BGU 162 viii 4, Amm.Marc. 17.4.14, cf. Poll. 7.191.
= trahea, Gloss.
κροκόδειλος, Hdt. 2.69, cj. in A. Supp. 878 (lyr.). (Egyptian msh, Arabic timsāh.)
goose, gen. χᾱνός Epich. 152, nom. χάν IG 42(1).122.133 ( Epid., iv B. C.); acc. pl. χᾶνας Ar. Ach. 878.
Canaanite, LXX Ge. 12.6. al.:—as Appellat., merchant (of Tyre or Sidon), Id. Pr. 31.24.

definition: χανδάνω, Hp. Mul. 1.78, Ep. impf. χάνδανε ( ν) Il. 23.742, Q.S. 12.328: fut. χείσομαι Od. 18.17: aor. ἔχᾰδον Il. 4.24, Ep. χάδον 11.462, inf. χαδεῖν Nic. Th. 956, Ep. and Ion. χαδέειν Il. 14.34, Hp. Genit. 9, part. χαδών Nic. Al. 145: pf. with pres. sense, κέχανδα and plpf. κεχάνδει ( κεχόνδει v.l. in Il. 24.192, ἐκεχάνδει Hsch.), v. infr.:—

children.definition: Ep. Verb (used once or twice in Ion. Prose, and once in Ar., v. infr.), take in, hold, contain, ἓξ δʼ ἄρα μέτρα χάνδανεν (sc. κρητήρ) Il. 23.742; λέβης τέσσαρα μέτρα κεχανδώς ib. 268; οὐκ ἐδυνήσατο πάσας αἰγιαλὸς νῆας χαδέειν 14.34; οἶκος κεχανδὼς πολλὰ καὶ ἐσθλά Od. 4.96; ὃς [θάλαμος] γλήνεα πολλὰ κεχάνδει Il. 24.192; οὐδὸς ἀμφοτέρους ὅδε χείσεται Od. 18.17; Ἥρῃ δʼ οὐκ ἔχαδε στῆθος χόλον the breast of Hera could not contain her rage (v.l. Ἥρη δʼ . . , Hera could not contain her anger in her breast), Il. 4.24; κρέας ὥς οἱ χεῖρες ἐχάνδανον as much as his hands could hold, Od. 17.344; ὅσον χανδάνει χείρ Hp. Mul. 1.78; [ ῥόπαλόν] οἱ ἐχάνδανε χείρ Theoc. 13.57, cf. Lyc. 317, Arat. 697.

data.quote: οὐκ ἐδυνήσατο πάσας αἰγιαλὸς νῆας χαδέειν

children.label: II
children.definition: to be capable, able, ἤϋσεν ὅσον κεφαλὴ χάδε φωτός Il. 11.462; κεκραξόμεσθά γʼ ὁπόσον ἡ φάρυξ ἂν ἡμῶν χανδάνῃ διʼ ἡμέρας Ar. Ra. 260; κωκύσασα . . ὅσσον ἐχάνδανε μητρὸς ἀνίη AP 7.644 (Bianor); ὅσον χάδον, ὅσσον ἔρεξαν Opp. C. 4.210: c. inf., στόμα χείσεται ἐξονομῆναι τοῦτο prob. for στοναχήσεται in h.Ven. 252. (Cf. Lat. pr(a)e-hendo; root χενδ- in χείσομαι ( χενδ-σ-) and κέχονδα (which shd. prob. be restored in Hom.); χα-ν-δ-άνω is formed from ἔχαδον ( ἔχṇδον).)

data.quote: κεκραξόμεσθά γʼ ὁπόσον ἡ φάρυξ ἂν ἡμῶν χανδάνῃ διʼ ἡμέρας

children.definition: with mouth wide open, greedily, eagerly, [ οἶνον] χ. ἑλεῖν Od. 21.294, cf. Call. Aet. 1.1.11 [Fr. 178.11 Pf.], Nic. Th. 341, Opp. C. 4.430 (cj.), etc.; in late Prose χ. ἐκπιεῖν, πιέσθαι, πίνειν, Gal. 15.735, Luc. Merc.Cond. 7, Jul. Mis. 338c; σπᾶν D.C. 71.10; metaph., χ. ἐνεπίμπλαντο εὐχῶν Luc. Alex. 14; χ. ἐμπιπλάμενος τοῦ ὕπνου Philostr. Im. 2.22.
toper, AP 11.59 ( Maced.).
yawning, roomy, ἐκ χανδῆς ζωροποτῶν κύλικος Epigr. ap. Polem.Hist. 79.
